[i]Far Cry 3[/i] got me back into games in a way I haven't been for years now. It came at the perfect time for me, and I had a great time with it. It's certainly not the best game ever, but it has some pretty nice shooting mechanics. I loved scouting out a camp, and marking everyone with my camera just to run in guns blazing. 

The story slowly started to grow on me. In someways it follows typical tropes, but other characters are so wild and exaggerated that they're genuinely scary. Honestly, the thing I enjoy most though is how exciting it is to go for the next upgrade. Every time I needed to go hunt rare animals to upgrade my backpack in one way or another was a blast. The world is pretty densely populated with interest areas, and it's pretty large. I'm glad I didn't go find all 120 relics hidden around the map. The graphics aren't fantastic anymore, but in 2021 [i]Far Cry 3[/i] is still a blast.

[b]Recommended[/b]

[i]If you found my review helpful, please consider following my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/44234346/]Steam Curator page[/url] where you can see more thoughts and recommendations[/i]

I should've played this game earlier on in it's proverbial lifecycle, and possibly even with freinds to test this co-op mode of theirs. As it stands, however, this is my opinion on the Singleplayer of Far Cry 3

Firstly: Story ain't so bad. It's not the most original thing, but it's a pretty decent and consistant narrative, so it's got my vote. The characters range from extremelly interesting (Vaas, Sam) to dull, boring and people i'd happily shoot (Buck, Dennis). Jason's charcter arc is pretty believable, and it does seem like he's made his intended change by the end of it. HOWEVER - The end of Far Cry 3 is utterly pointless. Being given a choice when there's only one "right" option is inane and stupid, and I'd much rather not have to choose. in that sense, the whole "regret" thing is somewhat ham-fisted towards the end of the narrative, but it's not terrible.

Secondly: Gunplay is good. enemies have weaker heads, gun variety expands early on, and has a good selection to choose from. Signature weapons feel underwhelming, but every weapon aside from those can be unlocked for free, either through story progression or through radio towers. Stealth, however, is a pile of wank.

It works well enough for the first half of the game, but once you see the privateers, all detecions on the enemy part get ramped up ludicrously. You take damage at an insane rate, armor barely helps, enemy detection starts working from 100+ meters away while you're in soft cover, and the entire game feels frustrating as all hell if you want to be sneaky. The only upside is Takedowns, which are varied, interesting and satisfying.

Animals are a mixed bag. Some animals are pointless to kill entirely, mostly birds and rats ect., but also any type of turtle or crocodile as well, and sharks to boot. They just drop low-vendor price selling material. All other animal skins can be used for crafting, and all upgrades to ammo space, storage space ect. can be achieved very quickly if you go after them like I did. However, some animals are despicable to fight. Bears specifically, due to their ability to chain-knock you down and prevent you from healing or running.

Fuck the healing system in this game. Armor only applies to bullets, so goodbye animal protection. Healing can be crafted, which is nice, but the healing animation has a "cast time", which can be interrupted both by you and enemies killing your ass while healing. which happens a LOT. Healing without medecine is possible, but don't even try if you're even CLOSE to another foe later on in the game, because that takes even LONGER. 80% of all crafted syringes are useless,
and 90% are useless outside of specific scenarios - the only ones worth crafting are Endorphin Boost, healing and Animal INstinct (with the special ones if you can be bothered to grab the bits).

Thirdly: the optional content. The side "story" quests are shallow, short and reward you with cash. The "kill this dude" ones are a massive pain in the ass if you want to go full-on sneak with them because of the lame stealth system, but can otherwise be mostly ok - but i'd personally not bother. The "hunt x with X" quests start off ok, but can get properly fucking insane (mainly with bears). They are necesary. however, if you want to get the top-tier storage stuffs - though only a select 10 or so. Supply drop quests are quick and easy money and XP, and radio towers are a mix between boring, 
slow and fucking stupidly difficult because it's platforming in a FPS, of course it is.

Finally: Collectibles are rewarding. Relics give XP, and unlock two special weapons and the two special recepies. Lost letters reward you with XP and a unique melee weapon. Memory cards give cash. The economy in the game is very stable for the most part, and the save system is pretty decent most of the time. However, what the worst thing of all is, is the slopes.

I fucking hate the slopes in this game. There are some areas (a lot) that are hilly, and if you spend over a second on them, in ANY WAY, you will slide down. I died more times to bullshit terrain design than I did to ANYTHING ELSE COMBINED. The game's height and depth are awesome, excpet when the game tells you "fuck yourdecision, you're going this way" and throws you off a mountain with the force of an angry god. For a game that touts exploration, it's quite annoying how very specific you have to be while exploring, if you want to get to where you want to go.

In conclusion: Far Cry 3 is pretty decent. The game plays well, only very occsionally crashes on selling or loading, Controls very well, the combat is excellent outside of stealth, enemies are varied and fair, though the second island is a pile of wank. Side content is shallow but rewarding and mercifully short, and exploring is a mix of: Getting ambushed by bears, finding something cool, and falling three feet to your death after the game decided your boots were now made of oil and the hillside was ice. Would recommend for a playthrough, would advise against completion due to hill physics and inane object placement.
It's a great game, well worth playing in any era. Hurk's missions are bonkers, the Japanese bunkers are great diversions, Agent Willis at his best. It's a classic.

One of the best FPS games ever, Far Cry 3 reinvented not only single-player shooters but also open world games in general. It's also one of the first games to nail stealth as a viable option instead of an obligatory or scripted playstyle. It's a beautiful game for its time although it doesn't have advanced physics and destruction like Crysis for example. Vaas Montenegro is one of the best gaming villains still to this day thanks to Michael Mando's (Better Call Saul) outstanding performance. If you're playing your same multiplayer game everyday instead of giving this a chance, remember this: the definition of insanity is doing the same thing over and over again.

Far Cry 3 is a 2012 first-person shooter game developed by Ubisoft Montreal and published by Ubisoft. It is the third main installment in the Far Cry series. The game takes place on the fictional Rook Islands, a tropical archipelago which can be freely explored by players. Gameplay focuses on combat and exploration. Players can use a variety of weapons to defeat human enemies and hostile wildlife, and the game features elements found in role-playing games such as skill trees and experience. After a vacation goes awry, protagonist Jason Brody must save his friends, who have been kidnapped by pirates, and escape from the island and its unhinged inhabitants.

    [tr]
        [td]üíæGraphics[/td]
        [td]The tropical island is absolutely stunning, even for a 2012 game it still stands pretty good in today‚Äôs standards. The only time this game looks kinda bad is when you are in caves. You get this odd glossy look in some areas and really stands out (note that I was playing on Ultra settings as well).[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üéÆGameplay[/td]
        [td]The gameplay is pretty simple, but really fun and engaging. Besides the story, you can clear out outposts, which secures areas of the map from bandits and gives you a sense of progression which was implemented greatly. You can earn perks from traditional gameplay and doing missions. The perk system is simple and easy to understand, so don‚Äôt expect bloated and useless perks here which is nice to see. You can also buy guns in this game, but if you‚Äôre patient, you can clear towers that make the map more visible and unlock weapons for free. You can add attachments to your weapons, but they are pretty basic (also you can add camo‚Äôs which is cool). Hunting also is pretty nice to see and adds purpose, for example if you hunt a specific animal you can improve your ammo capacity or weapon slots (and many more). If I had to find a complaint, the fall damage is absolutely ridiculous here as you can lose a ton of health if you fall like 6 feet, so be careful.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üìúStory[/td]
        [td]I felt like the story was actually really good here. You start off by having a blast with your friends and girlfriend, but soon you land on an island filled with pirates. A great villain in the name of Vaas will taunt you and do whatever it takes to k*ll you and your friends. The further you get into the story, the more you see yourself become an absolute killing machine. Vaas was a great villain with amazing writing. The voice actor did an amazing job with him and I would absolutely enjoy seeing him do more voice acting in the future. The boss fights are my biggest complaint here. Honestly it‚Äôs a complete joke. The fights are basically a quicktime event and really feels shitty since the villains are actually really good, it just sucks to see that they don‚Äôt have a memorable boss fight and it feels lazy. Besides that complaint, the story was really good.[/td]
    [/tr]

        [td]üïõPlaytime[/td]
        [td]Focusing mainly on the Story took me around 20+ hours to complete. There are some mini games and side missions you can do that will add some time to maybe 30 hours in total. [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üéßSound[/td]
        [td]The weapons sound incredible here. The voice acting is also really good, although the main protagonist does have some cringy dialogue and some of his lines are pretty bad, but other characters in the game do a really good job here. The music in this game ‚Äúfor the most part‚Äù is pretty lame, mostly talking about the action set pieces.[/td]
    [/tr]

        [td]‚ùóBugs‚ùó[/td]
        [td]I have encountered some bugs here. Some AI will get stuck, some bodies will float, also some weird graphical bugs (mostly in dark areas or in caves). Besides that, There were no serious bugs that took me out of the experience.[/td]

[h1] Far Cry 3 [/h1]
Far Cry 3 is often considered a beloved game for several reasons, earning praise from both players and critics. Here are some key factors contributing to its popularity:

1. [b]Engaging Storyline:[/b] Far Cry 3 features a compelling narrative that follows the protagonist, Jason Brody, as he navigates a dangerous and chaotic island filled with pirates and hostile wildlife. The storyline, particularly the character development and the descent of Jason into the world of violence and survival, captivated players.

2. [b]Memorable Characters:[/b] The game introduced memorable characters, including the iconic antagonist Vaas Montenegro. Vaas, in particular, is often cited as one of the most memorable and well-acted characters in gaming, adding depth and intensity to the overall experience.

3. [b]Open-World Exploration:[/b] Far Cry 3 offers a vast and visually stunning open-world environment that encourages exploration. Players can traverse a tropical island filled with diverse landscapes, wildlife, and enemy outposts. The freedom to approach objectives in different ways and the sense of discovery contributed to the game's appeal.

4. [b]Dynamic Gameplay:[/b] The game's first-person shooter mechanics were well-executed, offering a mix of stealth, gunplay, and melee combat. Players could use a variety of weapons, including a wide range of firearms and improvised weapons, to take on enemies and wildlife. The dynamic nature of encounters added to the excitement.

5. [b]Crafting and Progression System:[/b] Far Cry 3 introduced a crafting system where players could gather resources from the environment to craft items, upgrade equipment, and enhance their abilities. This added a layer of depth to the gameplay and gave players a sense of progression.

6. [b]Stunning Visuals and Atmosphere:[/b] The game boasted impressive graphics for its time, with a lush tropical setting and attention to detail in the environment. The atmospheric elements, day-night cycles, and weather effects enhanced the overall immersion.

7. [b]Player Choice:[/b] Far Cry 3 allowed players to approach missions and challenges in a non-linear fashion. The freedom to choose different paths and strategies added replayability and personalized the experience for each player.

8. [b]Innovative Multiplayer:[/b] While the single-player campaign received the most acclaim, Far Cry 3's multiplayer mode was praised for its unique take on team-based gameplay, incorporating elements from the single-player experience into competitive matches.

Overall, the combination of a strong narrative, well-designed open-world, memorable characters, and dynamic gameplay contributed to Far Cry 3's status as a beloved game in the first-person shooter genre.

Legendary game, still the best open world shooter, at least if you want fast-paced gameplay. Just did a playthrough again after several years with the Rakyat Mod, which I would highly recommend. You can find it on fcmodding.com, along with similar mods for most of the other games. The mod has lots of QOL features, like high FOV, viewmodel, quick loot, press to interact, etc. There are also lots of features that allow you to skip cutscenes, unlock the 2nd island from the beginning, start with more gear, earn money and xp faster, etc. And there are crazy options like allowing you to play as Rex Power Colt from Blood Dragon, sprint speed and lack of fall damage included.

So yeah this is more a review of the Rakyat mod than the game itself, but as you can see by my hours, I have played this game a lot over the last decade. 

Additional note: If you have trouble running the game on modern systems, especially with an AMD Ryzen CPU, you need to lock your FPS (probably to only 60 frames unfortunately) and then set your CPU core affinity to only 4 or 6 cores in task manager. I was have a lot of problems running the game until I did this. Guide here: https://www.reddit.com/r/farcry/comments/17vkw8m/far_cry_3_fix_crashing_performance_issues/?share_id=OZOd0jdacC2Gm2H5p7TVA&utm_content=1&utm_medium=android_app&utm_name=androidcss&utm_source=share&utm_term=1

"Far Cry 3" stands as a towering achievement in the world of open-world first-person shooters, striking a masterful balance between thrilling gameplay, compelling narrative, and a breathtakingly immersive environment. Set on a lush, yet perilous tropical island, the game plunges players into a harrowing tale of survival, betrayal, and transformation.

The game's protagonist, Jason Brody, is a relatable everyman thrust into extraordinary circumstances. His journey from a terrified tourist to a hardened warrior is both convincing and emotionally resonant, anchored by top-notch voice acting and a well-crafted script. The supporting cast, particularly the antagonist Vaas, portrayed by Michael Mando, brings an intensity and unpredictability that elevates the narrative to memorable heights.

"Far Cry 3" excels in its gameplay mechanics. The gunplay is tight and satisfying, allowing for a wide range of tactical approaches, from stealthy takedowns to all-out assaults. The game's arsenal is diverse, encouraging players to experiment with different weapons and strategies. The skill progression system is intuitive and rewarding, giving a tangible sense of development and empowerment.

The island itself is a character, teeming with wildlife, hidden treasures, and hostile forces. The attention to detail in the environment, from the lush jungles to the azure seas, is nothing short of astonishing. This vibrant setting is not just a backdrop but an interactive playground that offers a plethora of activities and side missions, which are as engaging as the main story.

The game also addresses mature themes with a thoughtful, if sometimes heavy-handed, approach. The descent into madness, the corrupting influence of power, and the blurred lines between sanity and insanity are themes that resonate throughout the narrative, adding depth to the gaming experience.

In terms of drawbacks, "Far Cry 3" occasionally falls into the trap of repetitive side missions, and some players might find certain plot points predictable. However, these are minor blemishes in an otherwise exceptional game.

In conclusion, "Far Cry 3" is not just a game; it's an experience. It's a journey into the heart of darkness that challenges both the protagonist and the player. With its captivating story, robust gameplay, and stunning visuals, it sets a high watermark for what an open-world game can achieve and remains a must-play title for any gaming enthusiast.

It is games like this that make me wish Steam had a neutral score option. Fundamentally, Far Cry 3 is a good game. However, the PC Port is laughably bad. Playing on a modern system, there are endless texture filtering issues (regardless of quality settings), poor UI scaling on high resolutions to the point where some elements of the interface overlap each other, and consistent crashing that is only redeemed by a somewhat generous autosaving system. In addition to the poor technical state, the Steam version is a glorified shortcut to launching Ubisoft Connect (formerly known as UPlay) which then launches the game itself. As a result, you have to do a mandatory online connection check with Ubisoft's servers, thus eliminating any ability to play the game offline despite the fact that its online content has been shut down.

When it comes to the game itself, it's hard not to like Far Cry 3. It's a fun and decently short action game with a fascinating villain. Vaas is one of the most easily recognizable and iconic game villains of all time, and that title is easily deserved. However, throughout the majority of the game the pacing is inconsistent and some plotpoints are incredibly contrived and convenient making the whole story feel less like something you control, and more like something you watch unfold. The combat can be clunky at times and the hunting and gathering mechanic is more tedious than its worth (primarily due to the limited space in your inventory in tandem with a lack of proper inventory management) however, for a campaign that can be completed in less than a dozen hours, it's worth setting aside a weekend and diving into the island.

In essence, it's hard to not recommend Far Cry 3, however, if you have any other means of playing the game, I would shy away from the Steam and the PC version in general.

This game had one of the best story in the entire series. I loved the gameplay, story, shooting, 1st person view & all the characters were written so brilliantly that i liked everyone of them. My favourite would be Vaas since his dialogues were pretty good. For eg: 'Do You Know The Definition Of Insanity'. Oh boi, that dialogue keeps coming up my mind everytime i play the game or when he comes in the cutscenes.
The things that i didn't like was the amount of loot chest were there in the game. It was so tiring and repetitive. Driving was like a love/hate type of relationship to me since 50% i liked the driving and 50% i don't sometimes. I don't like that Jason reloads the weapons very very very slowly. Like he takes 6 to 9 sec to reload the RPG's. And the most important thing which i didn't like was that the game crashed non stop in the middle and i always lose some progresses. I lost like so much time getting the collectibles and then re doing it again cause of the game crashing a lot in windows 11. And there are no autosave for picking collectibles as well, so i had to save every 2 mins when am done collecting stuff in houses, mountains, caves etc. 
I don't recommend this game to people who have Windows 11 and have high end PC. But you can buy it for nostalgia purposes and if you have an old PC with the old windows version then you can definitely play the game in peace without crashing.

TL;DR: Play the game. Be prepared to have fun, yes. Also be prepared to be annoyed as hell at its faults.

Fun:
- completely open world.
- only a few times are you channelled into a single choice.
- So many hours and I'm STILL discovering new things about the islands (new caves, new things to explore).

Top annoyances:
- unskippable cutscenes, even after the first time you've seen them. Developers who create those must hate their audience, or are perhaps TRYING to limit replayability. There's no excuse for them other than a towering sense of sadism on the part of developers. Or perhaps an even larger ego, in that they might believe their cutscenes are so good a person wants to see them over, and over, and over, and over? Nah, they're just sadists.
     My solution: Alt-tab and go do something else while they play out.
- unskippable cutscenes that require user input.
     My solution: grit my teeth and bear it, but each time it happens I want to play the game a 
     little less. Someday I'll just stop playing completely because of these.
- What do you mean I can't look around when driving/boating/flying????? Are you NUTS? Yeah, you can't turn your head when you're in control of a vehicle of any kind. One of the best Far Cry's in the series based on plot.

PROS :
- The map is pleasing, tropical but not oversaturated.
- The driving is incredible, both in the handling and the vehicle damage.
- Guns are satisfying to use, the recoil on each of them is balanced, and you really feel like you're using a powerful killing machines instead of a pea-shooters.
- VA is good, the NPCs are credible for the most part.
- The AI of the enemies is quite good, they are both clever and challenging, without having god-like omniscience.


CONS :
- Used to newer generation of games, the constant sliding on the side of mountains, trying to reach a collectible or an objective is frustrating in the beginning, infuriating after a while.
- I tried to collect a relic while on a side mission. "Mission failed" without warning, gotta start ALL OVER AGAIN. I hate the feeling of being tied to an objective and not wandering more than 5m of the authorized path.
- The system of rewards for clearing a radio tower is both unclear at the beginning and useless. By tower 3, you already bought the weapons that caught your eyes, so what's the point of waiting to get it for free ? (And cash is more than abundant to help you with your shopping spree).
- The vehicles despawn if you enter a cutscene/building. Nice, now i'm stranded on top of this mountain for the fifth time.


CONS (TECHNICAL) :
- The game regularly crashes for no reasons. I've a good pc, it's an old game without mods, shouldn't happen.
- The necessity to use Ubisoft's launcher (which doesn't remember your password, gotta type it twice every time) is BS at best, but I'm late to the party to shit on Papa Ubi.
- YES, i know your multiplayer service are offline, stop shoving it in my face every 5 min


CONCLUSION :

Far Cry 3 stands as a seminal title in the gaming landscape, inviting players on an enthralling journey into the heart of a lush and chaotic tropical paradise. This comprehensive review explores the game's exceptional qualities, from its organic gameplay to its layered narrative.

[h2] Graphics and Visuals [/h2]

[‚ùå] üí≠ A Little Repetitive: Far Cry 3, while captivating, can occasionally feel repetitive, especially in certain mission structures. The formulaic nature of some objectives might be a minor drawback for those seeking constant variety.

It's a good game but there are a few gripes I have with it. I'm not gonna bother with the positives since other people probably have said things better. Despite the negatives listed below I believe this is a game worth playing.

The save system. The game only allows you to at checkpoints during missions which makes it really annoying when you want to leave and come back where you left off. Sometimes you'll leave at what you think is a checkpoint only to come back and have to start the mission all over again.

Having to login to play the game. It's really annoying to have to login to uplay or whatever it's called every time you want to play. Added to the fact that the "Remember me on this device" checkbox doesn't even remember you makes opening the game a drag.

Lastly, Jason Brody (you, the main character) is pretty annoying. He come across as an impatient angsty hero  type of character which grates my ears every time he talks in cutscenes. This is honestly a minor gripe compared to how good the game is but it's so offputting since it contrasts against the other characters more lighthearted demeanors. 

My favourite thing in the game however is attacking outposts. Outposts are fun because they allow you to take them in any manner you choose, guns blazing, melee stealth (hard), or long-range sniping (which I enjoyed the most). One thing to note is that the game lowkey disincentivises going loud since it reduces the exp a lot which I find unfair due to the difficulty being higher than stealth.

Far Cry III takes players on an exhilarating journey through a stunningly beautiful open-world environment, delivering an unforgettable gaming experience. This game sets the standard for open-world adventure titles, effortlessly combining exciting gameplay, captivating storylines, and breathtaking visuals.

Gameplay ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ
Far Cry III offers an incredibly diverse range of gameplay options, allowing players to explore the vast tropical island of Rook Island at their own pace. From engaging in intense gunfights with enemy factions to embarking on thrilling side quests, the game never fails to keep players entertained. The ability to approach missions in various ways, including stealthily or with brute force, adds a layer of depth to the gameplay and keeps it fresh and exciting.

Storyline ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ
The immersive storyline of Far Cry III delves into the heart of darkness as players step into the shoes of Jason Brody, a stranded tourist turned reluctant hero. The narrative is expertly crafted, filled with unexpected twists, complex characters, and moral dilemmas. The emotionally-charged journey ensures that players are constantly engaged, making it difficult to put the controller down.

Visuals ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ
The visuals in Far Cry III are nothing short of breathtaking. The tropical paradise of Rook Island is meticulously detailed, with lush forests, sandy beaches, and vibrant wildlife that create a truly immersive environment. The attention to detail is evident in every aspect of the game, from the realistic character models to the stunning weather effects, making it a visual treat.

Sound ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ
The sound design in Far Cry III is truly remarkable, heightening the immersive experience. The haunting melodies and ambient sounds perfectly complement the game's atmosphere, creating a sense of tension and excitement. The voice acting is top-notch, bringing the characters to life and adding depth to the already compelling story.

Replayability ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ
Far Cry III offers hours upon hours of gameplay, with countless side quests, collectibles, and challenges to keep players engaged. Overall, Far Cry III is a masterpiece of game design, offering a stunning open-world experience with a compelling story, diverse gameplay options, and breathtaking visuals. It sets the bar high for future open-world adventure titles and is a must-play for any fan of the genre.

"Far Cry 3" stands as a pivotal installment in the franchise, delivering a thrilling open-world experience that blends action, exploration, and a captivating narrative. Set on a tropical island ruled by pirates, this game distinguishes itself through its compelling storyline, memorable characters, and expansive gameplay.

Compared to its predecessors, "Far Cry 3" significantly evolved the series by introducing a more nuanced narrative. The protagonist, Jason Brody, undergoes a transformative journey from an ordinary tourist to a skilled warrior, adding depth to the gameplay and storytelling. The game's antagonist, Vaas Montenegro, remains one of gaming's iconic villains, adding layers of depth and unpredictability to the narrative.

The game's open-world design is a triumph, offering players the freedom to explore the lush and diverse Rook Islands at their own pace. The island's flora and fauna, coupled with dynamic weather and day-night cycles, create an immersive environment ripe for exploration and discovery.

Gameplay-wise, "Far Cry 3" excels in providing a wide array of tools and tactics for players to approach combat situations. The freedom to engage enemies stealthily or go in guns blazing, combined with a skill tree that unlocks new abilities, adds depth to gameplay and encourages diverse playstyles.

However, while "Far Cry 3" received critical acclaim, some players might find certain aspects of the game formulaic or repetitive, especially when compared to its successors. The game's structure, including the liberation of outposts and the completion of side missions, might feel familiar to fans of the series.

Overall, "Far Cry 3" remains a standout title that rejuvenated the franchise. Its compelling narrative, immersive open world, and dynamic gameplay make it a highly recommended game for both fans of the series and newcomers. While later iterations brought enhancements and innovations, "Far Cry 3" remains an essential experience, offering a thrilling adventure amidst stunning landscapes and memorable characters.

Two things coming into this review surprised me, yes as everyone likes to rag on it is the first in a series of identical games *gameplay* wise. Additionally, there is a distinct plot device used in all 4 games up to far cry 6. But what there isn't, are identical themes. Far cry 3 is the weakest in the franchise, while being positioned as the best game for a number of other reasons. The very soul of this game, is a mutation on what could have been a very strong premise, but in order to shoot for prosperity was made juvenile. Immature. This is an MA15 game marketed towards 12 year olds. Every single aspect of this game is a byproduct of an era when marketing was locked into appealing towards schoolchildren. This entire game is marked by that strategy.

The game is fun, in passing. However it is predominately divided by excessive silence. A tiny fraction of my playtime was actually spent in combat related activities, the vast majority was spent just getting around the map in order to do sidequests and other minor objectives. What we call this today is padding, there is an obscene level of padding and we missed it because the idea was relatively new at the time. Nostalga is a deceptive thing. One of my greatest frustrations which ironically kept me playing long after I had grown bored, is the lack of opportunities to explore the open level design when approaching objectives or outposts. There seem to be a lot of outposts and things to do initially, but as the content starts to unfold you find that there are not enough things to really explore all the gear you can unlock and how it feels to use. I find myself testing anything I get on wildlife or in main missions when ideally I should know how it works.

Wrapping this up with the issue of the game's themes, it will only ever throw softballs at you. There is a rock solid set of systems that are genuinely extremely fun to explore, but the game is made trivial in complexity when presenting ways to use them. I know the reasoning for this, it must be intuitive for hormonal teenagers. Did you wonder to yourself about the excessive inclusion of drugs and sex? Maybe brushing it off as just a part of the game. Ubisoft did their jobs well if you thought the latter.  The idea that some guy from California can become a hardened warrior with respect and power because he took drugs and was given a tattoo from some freaky jungle shamans is a juvenile fantasy, yes I am intentionally reinforcing the idea it is juvenile. The weed mission was an egregious example. This was a game made for immature young men, reinforcing their immature young male fantasies. Narrative player growth is superficial (How much the experience can change YOU the player) and the entirety of the game has been molded into this more acceptable angle successfully for immortality of the franchise.

It was a sacrifice of what could have been a story few think to tell, like the tragic setting of the predecessor.  Future installments never again stoop to this depth, mechanically they are inferior to some degree and opinions are somewhat harsh on them for not being the original. But far cry 3 was an adolescent take on what would become a series of somewhat respectable narrative constructs.

This game is straight up fire. The story from beginning to end is one of the best stories i have ever seen before. This starts of as a group of friends, mc and siblings having fun on an island, then they get abducted. His brother dies in front of him then he almost dies and meet a guy. That guy changed his life with the will of the warrior. The mc's development is amazing compared from start to end. In the start he is the scared little guy who depends on his brother. In the end he is the strongest in the whole island and he does not care about the enemy and wants things to get done and do whatever he can to rescue all his friends and siblings. 

I really liked the crafting part of the game it makes this even more fun to play go around and looking for items to use for crafting. I also liked the skill unlocks in this game, after each mission you get skill points and with them you can get really cool skills that will help you in the future missions. Of course you can do the missions without the skills, but it will be much faster and easier with skills. The side quests will also give you some skill points if i am not mistaken.

The graphic is also good considering it came out in 2012 and i really enjoyed the game. The one thing i found a little irritating is that the text often just disappeared then i had to put on Fullscreen/windowed screen to get the text back. They shut down the online mode in the game, beacuse they use it for their new far cry games. All in all this game is absolutely worth playing, and enjoy the game!

This has been one of the more interesting games I've ever played. It takes you through the ideas of deception, surviving, and making the best in the reality you are in. I personally think the story is amazing, getting you to kill the antagonist who's killed your brother and then eventually ending the life of the man who's caused the  death and suffering of your friends. I would say the story becomes very confusing at times, and boring but when you first start it out, you've very interested in everything around the world and in the end, you're really enticed on helping the people of the island and allowing them to be free.

In addition to that, I would like to say that I have a low end PC, and running this at low graphics increased performance, but man was it still very beautiful, so, if you fear not being able to run it, I can assure you that you'll be fine. (I have an AMD A9 Chip, and I'm on a desktop with no pc) If you have a GTX or anything very new, then you'll have a very beautiful scenic island you can roam around.

Lastly, the story took me around 5-7 hours to complete in total, however, exploring new outposts and getting new radio towers adds more time to it. I spent like 20 hours in the game total doing all of those things whilst also completing the story.

A common thing now to scold Ubisoft games. But we still buy and play it. We do it, we disappoint, then we buy a new game and do this vicious circle again. 
And here I do the same. Today is harder to love Far Cry 3.  This game already can't give you sweet aftertaste. Even if you have those nostalgic feelings remembering how you played on release and liked it. They're gonna disappear very fast.
So, this is a typical Ubisoft game. Towers, towers, towers, similar one-minute quests, towers, towers, towers, similar side-activities. Treasure hunting - endless markers on the map. Among that is a story. And that story is wonderful. But our protagonist's characterization is poor. Jason Brody turns into Jason Statham in one moment. A gentle rich boy becomes a killing machine right after he gets a gun.  He is rude with his friends, makes delusional statements about his role on the island, and plays messiah. It's difficult to believe him. 

Did I ever tell you what the definition of insanity is?
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3066240481
Those famous words are Vaas's. Probably one of the best villains in video games. You can play Far Cry 3 only because of him. 

Nowadays the game unoptimized on current generation PCs and OS. All this time, I've been having performance issues while I've been playing the game. Freezes, stutters, FPS drops happened constantly on my setup (RTX 3080 + 11700k in 1080p). Settings changing was breaking resolution and only restart could help.

Every time after the first launch, the game starts Uplay and wants a password. Probably it is a plus, 'cause I finally remembered it. Is it plus, right? Also steam version has no achievements, but they're counted in your Uplay profile.  So trophy hunters can be calm. Or not... If you want platinum here - you have to complete co-op missions, but servers already are down. Anyway, there is mod which can help you to unlock online features, but still...

Long animations made me mad many times, because Jason changed weapon, recharged or healed himself very slow. Enemies prefer to rush you on difficult level without tactics. Or if I can name their outnumbering as advantage and a tactical move.

Bottom line is the game isn't already capable to impress you. Play only story quests and if you're okay with poor performance and annoying Uplay. Anyway the game is not bad and has own remarkable moments as Vaas or burning weed plantation mission.

This is not a negative review, mostly neutral, but I still can't recommend it. 
P.s. You can find all my short reviews [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/kiko_kitsune/recommended/]here[/url].

Man, I really wanted to give a positive review because some of my best memories come from this game, but in it's current state, DO NOT BUY, would be better to pirate the game or get a physical copy. 

Ubisoft forces you to have a Ubisoft account, which thankfully I do, and if you for some reason get disconnected from the online Ubisoft services, it just kicks you out of the game! I sure do love spending 30 minutes on a stealth mission to then just have to do it all over again. I hate the fact that this might become the standard for greedy companies like Ubisoft because it puts a lot of unneeded stress on the consumer, when all that should be done on the consumer's part is pay for the product that WE paid for and we should just be allow to enjoy it from there. 

And not to mention, you have to re-enter your Ubisoft login info EVERY TIME you launch the game, even if you clicked the "remember me" option.

Also one of the biggest disappointments for me, is there is no more map editor. Because multiplayer isn't supported anymore (which for me is fine, I never played this game for it's multiplayer anyways) but also gutting the amazing map editor also is a cardinal sin. 

Such an embarrassment for Ubisoft to make one of the most iconic games of all time to then just come in 11 years later and ruin it all, it truly is impressive.

This game's like that long-overdue adventure trip with friends, except instead of bonding over marshmallows, you're bonding over a shared hatred of Vaas, the deranged antagonist who's as crazy as a bag of cats on a rollercoaster.

The original Far Cry trilogy (or, if you count Instincts as a separate game from Far Cry 1, The Golden Age) comes to a close in this, a tight knit, well made, enjoyable as f**k, darkly humorous and surprisingly poignant open-world shooter.

The game continues the gameplay concepts introduced in Far Cry 2, whilst at the same time, removing the factors that turned off people from that game (Namely Weapon degradation and the Malaria attacks/missions) and introducing new survival-based features to fit with the new protagonist and storyline. The gunplay itself is as good as ever, with some killer weapons both traditional (rifles and shotguns) and non-traditional (A recurve bow and a flamethrower). The new levelling mechanic feels surprisingly at home, helping to even the odds in your favour, and the missions you get are varied, and pretty enjoyable (except for the Doppelganger mission in the main plot).  The survival mechanics also feel welcome and don't ruin everything, with the crafting system in particular feeling really good.

Finally, there's the story which is really damn good. Easily the best plot of the series, with its themes of brutality, sanity, descent into savagery, and manipulation, all of which are conveyed beautifully throughout. The characters are also well written and pretty likable, even the villains. And although I could say more about it, I feel it's for the best if YOU, the player, delve in for yourself.

All in all, Far Cry 3 wraps up the franchise's golden years with a fluid, satisfying shooter and one of the best games of the golden age of gaming in general. If you're a fan of shooters and looking for an open world affair that's actually good/a game that lets you approach any situation the way you want to, Far Cry 3, and with it, the original Far Cry games in general, just can't be beat.

EDIT: I finally played the Blood Dragon expansion. It's fantastic!

The Story:

Far Cry 3's story is a standout feature. You play as Jason Brody, a regular guy stuck on a dangerous tropical island. The island is controlled by a menacing villain, Vaas Montenegro. Jason's transformation from a scared newbie to a tough hero is gripping, and the character development and psychological struggle make the story unforgettable.

Gameplay:

The gameplay is where Far Cry 3 excels. The open world is filled with activities, from hunting animals to crafting items and engaging in intense battles. You have the freedom to approach missions and fights as you like, whether you prefer stealth or going in guns blazing. The variety of weapons and vehicles keeps things fresh and exciting.

Graphics and Setting:

Far Cry 3's tropical setting is stunning. The island is beautifully detailed, with lush jungles, clear waters, and diverse landscapes. The game's graphics and the size of the world are impressive, making exploration a real treat.

Character Development:

Watching Jason's transformation and the well-written supporting characters add depth to the story. Your choices affect the outcome, giving you a sense of control in the game's narrative.

Conclusion:

Far Cry 3 is a top-notch open-world game with a compelling story, addictive gameplay, and a visually stunning world. Its enduring popularity is a testament to its quality. If you haven't played it yet, you're missing out on an unforgettable gaming experience in a thrilling tropical paradise.

[h1] IT'S SNOW WHITE! [/h1]

When it comes to gameplay, the Far Cry series has always delivered a fairly strong experience.  The last offering really tried to make the game more of a sandbox and provide more plot, but it often got bogged down in its own features.  Far Cry 3 plays out as a brand-new experience as much as it does as a culmination of the series.  The game is a sandbox shooter filled with options, but for the first time in the franchise, the gameplay feels cohesive.

You play as Jason Brody, a twenty-something on a trip with his friends when it goes horribly wrong.  During a skydive, the group is captured and separated by a band of pirates led by a man named Vaas. Jason wakes up with his brother in a makeshift cage in the middle of a jungle encampment.  Jason escapes and wakes up essentially drafted into the island's rebel forces, who are struggling against the pirates who almost fully control the island.  With their support and guidance, Jason begins to work toward freeing his friends and getting the hell off of the island.

Jason's evolution as a character is particularly noteworthy, as at the outset of the game, he has literally never fired a gun before and nearly loses his wits during his escape.  Over the course of the game, you gain strength in the form of the expected new weapons and abilities, but the narrative also has Jason evolving as he becomes accustomed to his ability to skulk through the jungle and kill.  It's interesting to experience his transition ‚Äî and equally interesting to see how his friends react to Jason's increasingly flippant nature toward taking lives.

It's not just Jason's character development that experiences a gradual transition.  At the beginning of the game, you barely have any skills, short of sprinting short distances and the basic use of a firearm.  As you kill pirates and complete missions, you gain experience and levels, with each level granting you a skill point to spend in one of three trees.  At the start, skills are basic, like the ability to cook a grenade or slide along the ground.  Later skills are what really increase your feeling of being a badass, such as leaping from a rooftop and taking down someone silently or killing two enemies at once while you swim beneath the dock.

This gradual progression of skills and abilities is arguably more important than increasing your armory.  Early in the game, if you see two guards and want to take out both, you must throw a rock to distract one or use a silenced pistol to shoot one and immediately stab the other.  As you gain skills, your options improve, such as leaping from a rooftop and take out both or killing one and pulling a knife from his belt to throw at the other.  Since the game gradually introduces you to these abilities, you also slowly incorporate them into your gameplay, and you tend to use the majority of them by the end of the game.

That's not to say that your armory's growth is entirely inconsequential.  There's a wide array of options when it comes to arming yourself, from the stealth options of silenced weapons or the compound bow to far more aggressive selections, such as shotguns and assault rifles.  Many of the weapons can also be modified, such as adding the aforementioned silencers, scopes or extended magazines.  However, not all weapons can be modified, and even those that can seem to only have a few no-brainer selections. Some weapons are more based on preference rather than any real benefit.  Still, it allows you to have a bit more ownership of your gear, and you can even personalize them with paint jobs.

The interface that you use to craft items or manage your inventory is quite cumbersome.  Everything is buried in multiple submenus, and while double-clicking them enters, you must click on a button at the bottom to back up a level.  This makes it a pain to quickly jump between different areas, such as when you are taking stock of the pelts needed to make the next batch of upgrades.  Your rucksack inventory is easier to manage, mainly due to the existence of a quick-sell button that immediately sells all junk items.  Selling items that are considered actually useful is far less smooth, as every time you sell an item, the rest of the inventory resorts itself.  If you wanted to sell two dingo pelts, you'll sell the first one and then must find where the other shuffled itself ‚Äî even if it used to be right next to it.

Using the stealthy approach to the game is just as viable as running into every enemy group with guns blazing, though the former is a lot more entertaining.  Guards actually fan out and try to secure the area when threatened, and you can also use this to your advantage, though it'll be far harder to get the drop on them.  There's a good bonus for doing things stealthily when taking out strongholds, but that's the only area where it matters.  Any other time, you can use shotguns and grenade launchers to your heart's content, and even then, if you use them to wipe out a stronghold, you'll still have plenty of skill points to spend in the areas that you really want.

The plot is pretty straightforward, with Jason slowly becoming assimilated into the rebel culture and losing his grip on his sense of self.  What makes the plot memorable is the voice acting, with virtually every character coming across as either genuinely well grounded or completely insane.  No one carries the latter mantle better than Vaas, and you'll want to catch up to the parts of the game where you encounter him just to listen to his special brand of crazy.  Predictable story or no, it's put together well and delivered in such a way that it doesn't seem to cover overly trodden ground.

Thankfully, the plot isn't the only thread that pulls you back to the game.  Ultimately, the biggest reason for that is because of how well the different aspects are balanced.  You'll break up doing missions by taking over a tower, and then maybe do a spree of stronghold assaults punctuated by hunting feral tigers with little more than a bow and arrow.  All of it is entertaining, and it gives you a sense that the island is little more than your plaything‚Äî a feeling that's only emphasized as your skills increase and you become a badass cross between Turok and Rambo.  It's for that reason that Far Cry 3 comes across as a fresh experience and ranks up there as one of the best shooters of 2012.

[h1]The Unforgettable Journey[/h1]

[i]There will be a TL;DR at the end[/i].

~

I've always come back to Far Cry 3 after many years.
Played through it twice over on my 360, and thoroughly enjoyed my time with it here on Steam.

The most important thing to know about this game is that it is a cornerstone that changed the trajectory of the gaming landscape.
Far Cry 3 was when Ubisoft truly discovered the power of its core formula and put it to practice in its most pure form.
The world is fresh, alive, and teeming with possibilities.
The scenic vistas of the beautiful islands, the culture of the people, the harrowing dangers of the wilderness, the frantic panic of combat, and the wonder as the secrets of local history unfold before you.
It is truly an immersive experience.

The interesting thing about the franchise is how stale and wayward it has truly became after trying to chase the coat-tail of this installment, which was lightning in a bottle.

The base line that everyone knows and has grown tired of is here: Open world, lots of weapons, upgrades, skill tree, lots of side quests, tons of fetching and hunting down items, outpost liberation, and guerrilla skirmishes - tied with a charismatic antagonist that is clearly insane, poor writing, and a vivid landscape to get lost in between encounters.

The thing that elevates this game over the others is its masterful demonstration of THEME.
The Rook Islands are alive with their own culture, and the aspect of the game where Brody (Snow White) slowly transforms from a city frat boy into a fierce and unstoppable animal with enough PTSD to fund a therapist for life - it's breathing through each and every piece of the world as you explore.

- The setting isn't rural America, cities, or mountains, it is tropical jungle. Instinctual, it is a kill-or-be-killed setting where beauty is only matched by brutality. It fits perfectly.
- The local culture revolves around bestial fetishes and idols that depict hunters, with the player's own exploration of gameplay serving to draw Brody closer to this ideology.
- The accumulation of weapons, abilities, and items allow players to become far more deadly and liberal in their approach, which correlates with the thesis of Brody becoming more deadly.
- Wildlife ranges from lemurs and hogs to sharks and tigers, there is always something to hunt and always something hunting you.
- The desperation of the locals mixed with their muted interactions and the poor writing of other jerky Americans serve to illustrate Brody's separation from civility and society at large and his decline into a feral warrior.
- The villains swap (Unfortunately so) with the insane villain posing an initial threat as Brody has to conquer the chaos and inanity of the wilderness to survive, but transforms into a smart and coordinated outsider... which serves to show that Brody's new enemy is the trappings of civility and higher function.
- The rolling landscape seems daunting at first, but traversal becomes so fluid and easy by the end that, like Brody, players stumble through their opening hours like an infant - but then forge themselves into efficient and ruthless warriors.

The beauty of Far Cry 3 is that Brody is just a catalyst for the player.
YOU start out weak and confused.
YOU start out lost and insufficient.
By the end, YOU are the apex predator.
By the end, YOU have to ask the question if ytou're ready to put the game down and accept that it's over, or keep on playing.

The ending videos themselves are horrible. Very poor options for such a game - but they serve their purpose.

Far Cry 3 is more than a dumb game.
Far Cry 3 is more than Ubisoft finding a formula that works.
Far Cry 3 is more than a fantastical escape.

Far Cry 3 is a philosophical journey that you, the player, is pushed through and molded by.
When you are finished with the game, you will have felt as though you've grown beside it.

Far Cry 3 is an unforgettable experience.

~

[h3]TL;DR[/h3]
[b]9.5/10[/b].
[i]Far Cry 3[/i] is an [b]Exceptional[/b] game.
There are footfalls and shortcomings, but when you emerge on the other side of its sprawling jungles and set-pieces, you will find a piece of yourself that has long been buried in the back of your mind. Brody may be the mouthpiece, but for the game's time - you rose to become something else.

Far Cry 3 is a 2012 first-person shooter game developed by Ubisoft Montreal and published by Ubisoft. It is the third main installment in the Far Cry series after Far Cry 2. The game takes place on the fictional Rook Islands, a tropical archipelago which can be freely explored by players. Gameplay focuses on combat and exploration. Players can use a variety of weapons to defeat human enemies and hostile wildlife, and the game features elements found in role-playing games such as skill trees and experience. After a vacation goes awry, protagonist Jason Brody must save his friends, who have been kidnapped by pirates, and escape from the island and its unhinged inhabitants.

Ubisoft Montreal collaborated with Ubisoft's global development team, including Massive Entertainment, Ubisoft Shanghai, Ubisoft Bucharest, Ubisoft Reflections and Red Storm Entertainment. The game's development was partially restarted in 2010 after the departure of several key creative staff. The team evaluated the feedback for Far Cry 2 and identified areas that needed to be improved or removed. The team spent considerable time designing the island, which they described as the "second most important character" in the game. Inspirations were taken from films and TV shows such as Apocalypse Now and Lost, as well as video games The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim and Red Dead Redemption. Michael Mando was hired to portray Vaas Montenegro, an antagonist the team compared to Darth Vader.

The game was announced in June 2011 and Ubisoft promoted the game with various companion apps, webseries and crossover. It was released for Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360 in November 2012. The game received critical acclaim upon release, with praise directed at its characters (particularly Vaas), world design, visuals, progression, and gameplay, though the game's multiplayer modes received criticism. Despite weak pre-order sales, the game was a commercial success, selling 10 million copies. It was nominated for multiple year-end accolades including Game of the Year and Best Shooter awards by several gaming publications. It has also been cited as one of the greatest video games ever made. Ubisoft supported the game with downloadable content and released Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon, the game's standalone expansion, in 2013. A successor, Far Cry 4 was released in November 2014. The game was re-released for PlayStation 4 and Xbox One in June 2018.

What's not to like? It's Far Cry 4, 5 and New Dawn, but old school. The graphics are still great by today's standards, the controls are familiar, and the idea was pretty much the same back in 2012 as it is now: You activate radio towers to open up new map areas, liberate outposts, complete challenges, hunt animals for money or crafting supplies, and complete missions to progress.

Like the other Far Cry games, you start out being captured by the bad guys, and fight against all odds to escape, arm yourself and find your missing friends. You are befriended by the locals, who teach you how to fight, and in turn you become their reluctant hero. 

Far Cry 3 is every bit as immersive and engaging as the newer games in the series. I didn't expect it to be this good, since it's 11 years old, but it has aged well. It's fun, and I'll be completely hooked until I finish it.

For me, the only downside is where animals show up. Tigers, in particular, are EVERYWHERE. There's no rhyme or reason to where they spawn. I haven't seen so many of them since I lived in Detroit. But, unlike the Detroit variety, these Tigers get the job done. Just as in real life, once a tiger gets you just give it up: You're cat food. It happens annoyingly often. Maybe the developers were shooting for reality by randomly placing them everywhere. It could be just a fact of life that tigers wander the back yards in some parts of SE Asia. I'm no world traveler, so I don't know, but I can say that the American equivalent would be getting attacked by mountain lions every single time I run to the grocery store.

Enough about tigers. If you enjoy action, exploration, a few puzzles and shooting bad guys with a variety of modified firearms, I recommend Far Cry 3. You won't be sorry, especially with the 2012 price tag.

[b] Far Cry 3 is an absolute gem in the world of gaming, and it has left an indelible mark on me as a player. I purchased this game quite some time ago, and it has continued to be a source of enjoyment and excitement.

One of the most memorable aspects of Far Cry 3 is its captivating storyline. It pulled me into the world of Rook Islands, a lush and dangerous tropical paradise, and kept me engaged from start to finish. The protagonist, Jason Brody, undergoes a remarkable transformation as he fights for survival and seeks to rescue his friends. The characters, including the unforgettable villain Vaas Montenegro, are expertly crafted and bring the story to life in a truly immersive way.

The open-world exploration in Far Cry 3 is a true highlight. The vast and beautifully designed landscape of Rook Islands encourages players to venture off the beaten path, discover hidden treasures, and engage in thrilling encounters with both wildlife and hostile mercenaries. Whether I was navigating dense jungles, scaling cliffs, or liberating outposts, the sense of freedom and discovery was unparalleled.

The gameplay mechanics are solid, and the ability to approach missions and challenges in various ways is a testament to the game's versatility. From stealthy takedowns to all-out gunfights, Far Cry 3 caters to a wide range of playstyles. The progression system and crafting mechanics add depth to the experience, making it feel rewarding to invest time in upgrading equipment and skills.

I also have fond memories of playing Far Cry 3 cooperatively with friends. The ability to explore the island, complete missions, and create our own adventures together added a whole new layer of enjoyment to an already fantastic game.

Years after its release, Far Cry 3 remains my go-to recommendation for anyone looking for a captivating single-player experience with an open-world twist. Its combination of a gripping narrative, stunning visuals, and diverse gameplay options make it a true classic in the gaming world. [/b]

Having played Far Cry 2 relatively recently, I must say that the improvements from FC2 to FC3 are considerable.

I liked the main story a lot. It was fully of nuanced and interesting characters, strong voice acting and some really interesting cut scenes. Unfortunately it had a noticeable dip in quality towards the end. There was a point earlier in the story where it had made more sense to end the game in my opinion. Even so, I still enjoyed the experience.

Overall game play was very satisfying as well, being able to craft drugs from plants in the "jungle" depending on what you needed at the time made it interesting to plan ahead and predict your needs. It also made it slightly more fun to grind all the outposts and radio towers in the game.

On that note, pretty much all side content in terms of quests, challenges, trials etc are very dull and repetitive. I would personally have preferred 2-3 interesting side quests that were a bit longer to the larger amounts of activities that not only were quite boring, but also felt completely out of place.

All in all I still recommend the game, but I would only recommend playing the main story line. Make sure to only craft, grind radio towers and liberate outposts as they are required, any more has no impact whatsoever on the game as a whole.

i remember playing this 10 years ago as a teenager and thinking it was an awe-striking masterpiece. whereas nowadays i see a dysfunctional, overrated hunk of junk that stands as one of the most broken and poorly optimized games Ubisoft has ever put out. however, after spending nearly 50 hours with it i can safely say that it does indeed have some very unique elements that make the experience worth your troubles... probably.

the writing is at many times cartoonish, nonsensical and even unbearably cringe, but there are some very interesting concepts being worked in the overall narrative and also some really neat and original (for the time) stylistic choices. gameplay is plagued by flawed design decisions, barebones AI, buggy mechanics, sporadic crashing and an endless amount of meaningless busy work that only serves to inflate the amount of optional "content" available, but you'll find some really intense and thrilling setpieces across the main story missions, and the feature rich combat can be quite satisfying when it works as intended. there are aggressively frequent texture streaming issues, several comically malfunctioning effects (such as Far Cry 3's infamous ambient occlusion, which generates shadow halos around all objects), a barrage of graphical inconsistencies and glitches, and lots of locations that seem unfinished to say the least, but if you can put up with all that you'll also find plenty of beautiful scenery and cinematic vistas during your exploration sessions.

overall, Far Cry 3 is a very uneven experience, but one that ends up deserving your time investment thanks to the things it manages to get right in very memorable and flamboyant ways. it's definitely not the masterpiece the nostalgia fueled bandwagon would have you think, but it's certainly worth checking out. by the way, the main theme song is an absolute banger.

Far Cry 3 Review

Review is after completing the main story missions, side missions and clearing out the entire map: both maps.
[hr][/hr]


[b]Story[/b]
[Positive] Learned about the definition of insanity!
[Negative] The aforementioned definer of insanity was the only villain this tale needed.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
[Positive] Tower climbing puzzles and map reveal was magical at the time. Exploration was addictive.
[Positive] Outpost battles were tons of fun. Allowed for many varied approaches.
[Positive] Bow and Arrow gameplay. Explosive recurve bow.
[Positive] Fire spread as good as Far Cry 2.
[Positive] Wildlife hunting and skins to upgrades. I did most of these before the majority of the exploration to have a smoother experience.
[Positive] Varied means of transport. 
[Positive] The cementing of the infamous Ubisoft formula.
[Positive] Interesting treasure hunting.
[Positive] Knife throwing mini game!

[Negative] Remember to say no to drug syringes and gambling though.
[Negative] Also no need for quick time events for boss battles.
[Negative] Hang gliders were deadly though. Ziplines were not placed very strategically so never used them much.
[Negative] The famous Burning drug farm with flamethrower section: I got shot at so it wasn‚Äôt fun and so I missed the magic of that moment.
[Negative] I bought this game because I enjoyed Far Cry 2. A change from the realism in Far Cry 2 map holding and malaria.

[b]Graphics[/b]
Environments and character graphics were done really well. No complains from me.


[b]Controls[/b]
Played on PC with mouse and keyboard. Gunplay was smooth and responsive. 


[b]Side Missions[/b]
There are a few side missions and challenges in this game. I was able to complete most of them as part of clearing the map. Actually in retrospect clearing the map was the biggest and most enjoyable side quest.


[b]Music/Soundtrack/Voice[/b]
Didn't really notice the soundtrack here much. No complaints here. Decent voice acting by the games characters and excellent voice acting by the definer of insanity.


[b]Performance[/b]
Experienced no crashes and the game ran smoothly on my PC (which is a mid-range PC). It did not cause undue heating of the CPU and GPU.


Overall Score 9/10

Title: An Island of Unforgettable Chaos - My Review of "Far Cry 3"

"Far Cry 3" is a game that can only be described as a visceral roller-coaster through the untamed heart of a tropical paradise. From the moment you crash land on the lush Rook Islands, you're thrown headfirst into a world of chaos and survival. This review aims to capture the essence of a game that has left an indelible mark on the open-world genre.

"Far Cry 3's" game-play is nothing short of exhilarating. The moment you pick up the controller, you're dropped into a massive, open sandbox filled with an abundance of missions, side activities, and wildlife that's just as eager to eat you as it is to be hunted. The seamless blend of first-person shooting, stealth, and exploration is a testament to the game's brilliance. From the intense firefights to silently taking down pirates with your trusty machete, every moment feels like a unique adventure.

The narrative of "Far Cry 3" is a masterpiece of psychological thriller meets tropical survival. You play as Jason Brody, a young man who finds himself stranded on the lawless Rook Islands after a skydiving trip goes horribly wrong. As he searches for his kidnapped friends, he's forced to confront the island's twisted inhabitants, especially the unforgettable villain, Vaas Montenegro. Vaas is a character so captivatingly unhinged that he steals every scene he's in.

The story's journey from Jason's initial naivety to his transformation into a true warrior is a captivating one. The game tackles themes of insanity, morality, and the thin line between civilization and savagery. It's a psychological roller-coaster that keeps you engaged from start to finish.

"Far Cry 3's" visuals were stunning when it first released, and they still hold up remarkably well. The tropical island setting is beautifully rendered, with lush forests, pristine beaches, and underwater caves that beg exploration. The attention to detail is commendable, making the Rook Islands feel alive and dynamic.

The audio design is equally impressive. The hauntingly atmospheric score sets the tone perfectly, while the voice acting, particularly from Michael Mando as Vaas, is nothing short of exceptional. The ambient sounds of the jungle, wildlife, and combat add to the game's immersive quality.

"Far Cry 3" offers a wealth of content to keep players coming back for more. Side quests, hunting challenges, and collectibles are scattered throughout the island, ensuring that there's always something to do. The freedom to tackle objectives in various ways, whether through stealth, guns blazing, or creative tactics, adds immense replay value.

In addition, the game's robust multiplayer mode allows players to engage in intense matches with friends, from classic death-matches to more unique game modes. The competitive aspect is a welcome addition for those looking to extend their "Far Cry 3" experience beyond the single-player campaign.

In the end, "Far Cry 3" is a timeless gem in the world of gaming. Its gripping story, outstanding game-play, and immersive world design come together to create an unforgettable experience. Whether you're a first-time player or revisiting the Rook Islands, this game guarantees an adventure like no other. Just remember, insanity is doing the same thing over and over again and expecting different results, and with "Far Cry 3", you'll want to experience its madness again and again.

At its core, FC3 is really good, one of the best Far Cry games no doubt. Unfortunately, it has two major issues which is why I can't recommend it.

First, the multilayer and co-op are no longer functional as Ubisoft killed the online service so you aren't getting the complete package. If you buy the game through Steam you still need the Ubisoft Connect launcher to play the game. This isn't unique to FC3, all Ubisoft games have this requirement now. I also really hate that the achievements are only in the Ubisoft launcher and not on Stream.

Second, the game is a technical mess. When the game came out it had issues and they've only gotten worse. FC3 is horribly optimized for PC, especially modern PCs. By default it has negative mouse acceleration which makes aiming with a m&k practically impossible until you fix it (can't be turned off in-game). It has constant microstutters and frame drops and (at least on my system) it crashes constantly. I beat the game in about 20 hours on the hardest difficulty and in that time it probably crashes at least 50 times, often right before completing a mission. I attempted every fix I could find which did make the game playable at least. Before it would crash 5 minutes into the first mission. But, even after all the fixes it still crashed pretty often. All of this on top of a ton of bugs and glitches throughout the game.

For me at least, I couldn't truly enjoy the game due to all the technical problems. Even gameplay wise I enjoyed FC4 and FC5 more as I feel the gameplay loop is more fleshed out and refined in those games. At least it's not being sold at full price unlike the older CoDs.

Let me start by stating that this game is absolutely unique. Far Cry 3 differs from practically every other first-person shooter on the market thanks to two crucial components: gameplay and story. I'll begin with the narrative. This game's narrative is wholly original. It starts off as clich√©d as your typical B action movie but it eventually changes into something completely unexpected. The game's primary focus in the beginning is to save your friends from some evil pirates but the plot twists about half way through and begins exploring some dark and very uncomfortable realms. Without spoiling anything, you'll want to replay this story due to the sheer amount of possibilities the game allows. That's where the element of gameplay comes in. Far Cry 3 has your standard FPS mechanics and a plethora of weapons and attachments, alongside amazing enemy AI, dangerous wild animals, and a huge tropical island to explore. The missions can all be done in different ways, whether you prefer stealth with silenced weapons, or go in guns blazing with a rocket launcher and grenades, player choice is a key element. Besides the story missions you can also hunt wild animals (deer, buffalo, tigers, boars, pigs, deer, dingos, sharks, and alligators just to name a few), take over enemy pirate bases, engage in side quests for the Rakyat tribe, compete in races, fly on hang gliders, skydive, or just explore the island at your leisure. The only negative aspect about Far Cry 3 is that a couple of the missions drag on at a few points, but that's such a minuscule complaint compared to the greatness of the rest of the game. Far Cry 3's story will really make you think about what you're doing and why you're doing it, the main character delves deeper and deeper into uncomfortable realms and insanity, which I will not go into detail about in this review, but they're definitely worth playing through the game to see. Jason Brody's transformation is one that will leave you questioning yourself at certain points, especially at the game's ending.

A must-play game for all the PC gamers out there. Tons of things to like about this game such as:

1.  Rook Island is a vast and beautiful location, and there's always something to do, whether you're exploring the jungle, hunting animals, or taking on enemy strongholds.
2. There are a variety of weapons and gadgets to choose from, and you can approach fights in a variety of ways. Whether you prefer to go in guns blazing or take a more stealthy approach, you're sure to find a playstyle that suits you.
3. Jason Brody is a relatable protagonist, and his journey from carefree tourist to hardened survivor is both exciting and emotionally resonant.
4. From Vaas Montenegro, the charismatic and unhinged villain, to Citra Talugmai, the mysterious and alluring leader of the Rakyat, the cast of FarCry 3 is one of the best in the series.
5. The game's setting is incredibly well-realized. Rook Island is a lush and vibrant jungle, and the game does a great job of immersing you in the environment.
6. The game's progression system is well-designed. As you progress through the game, you'll unlock new weapons, abilities, and upgrades, which will give you more options for how to approach challenges.

The game in itself is AMAZING, I don't know why I had never played anything from the Far Cry series until this year, but I've purchased the game in a summer sale (a while ago) and it was definitely worth it. 

Even though FC3 was released in 2012, the game's plot is very original, and actually emotional, you will be playing as Jason Brody and you and your friends got kidnapped by (one of the best villains I've ever seen in games) Vaas Montenegro, now to escape this island you'll have to become basically a mass murderer, animal hunter, fuck a hot bitch - if you want it "), and etc etc, anyway, point is you'll be addicted to this game real fast. The game is a FPS/RPG but since it was from 2012, it does not have a great variety of options but they do have classic RPG elements like crafting, skills that you learn, etc

I was also impressed with the cutscenes and the way that they chose and approach the manner that they tell this story, it affects directly your experience to a point where the graphics don't really matter that much - obv it's not the best in 2023.

I'm not really gonna go in much details about it, it's not super hard to learn the mechanichs, but it is a little hard to master.

Now, despite the fact that the game is really fucking good, I do have to point out that Ubisoft SUCKS INCREDIBLY, I know this is old news and everything but, at one point I couldn't even launch the game via Steam or Ubisoft Connect, which is something I've never seen in any other platform, and that's why my analysis will display something like 4 hours of gameplay. 

I found like two weeks ago the solution and finished most of the game by this point, and reached I would guess at least 40 hrs of gameplay.

IF YOU DON'T WANT TO READ ALL OF THAT, YOU MAY JUST SKIP TO THIS POINT AS WELL:

In conclusion: is the game worth it? YES, a million times, BUT, you'll probably have to deal with Ubisoft and this will definitely leave you flustered and angry. But also wait for a sale, it will be the best moment to buy FC3.
