There are so many things wrong, I don't know where to start.

First, Steam ... c'mon.  This is supposed to be a professional outfit here.  Why do you force people into an all or nothing, completely binary review.  You either thumbs-up the game i.e. you like it 100% or you thumbs-down a game meaning you dislike a game 100%.  Why isn't there a more nuanced rating system like ascribing a number of stars based on how well you like a game.  Instead of forcing people to always put in their comments:  "Well I have to give the game a thumbs-up because I like it 51% and dislike it 49%"  (or something similar).

Second, as literally everyone can attest to - I cannot stand it when games require you log into a third party program that you, of course, have to download and install onto your computer;  a program that isn't one that just sits in your hard drive but also becomes part of the registry.  Why.  WHY do you do this?  You know we all hate it and your games get much worse reviews than they otherwise would if you stopped this crap.  I don't like my computer being swamped with these stupid little programs one has to keep logging into, for one thing, and secondly, I don't like how it's just another form of control.  It's like you don't actually buy games anymore.  You rent them.  And the company can pull the plug on a game you spent good money for - whenever it wants to.  That's crap.

Third - enough with the security.  I'm sick and tired of programs that have a "Remember Me?"  checkbox - only for the program to ignore it even when you tick it.  I'm tired of having to enter a password two or three times just to access a game.  My bank doesn't require so many layers of useless security.  

Early in the game, it's annoying doing any of the hunting quests because you MUST use a specific weapon.  When you can only carry one or two guns, having one of them replaced by, say, a sniper rifle, is annoying.  Because whatever weapon you're carrying, you throw on the ground.  And it won't be there when you complete the quest.  Sure, you can go all the way back to town and re-equip it, but it's still annoying.

Enemies will spawn in out of nowhere.  This usually applies to animals, not necessarily pirates.   I guess they hope you'll think you just "missed" the sneaky animals in high brush.  But I've been in places where there was nowhere for an animal to hide - and yet there it is, killing me.  Wasn't there 2 seconds ago.  Often it's more than one.  A pack of wild dogs.  Two or three komodo dragons, etc.    I guarantee it - you will be asking repeatedly, "Where did those things come from?"  Well, they just spawned in.  Poof.  All the sudden - like the transporters from Star Trek.  They're just there.  And they come to attack you.  It happens a lot when you're vulnerable - low on ammo, low on health, need to reload, facing the wrong way, etc.  I shot a goat from a ledge - and when I dropped down to get the skin for crafting, two komodo dragons pounced on me the moment my feet hit the ground.  I would have seen one komodo dragon - much less two of them - because I had a bird's eye view of the area and it was open terrain - no brush, weeds, or places to hide.  Obviously they spawned in.  When the game wants you to die - you'll die - even if it has to spawn 3 or 4 tigers to do it.

This is the kind of game that captures your monitor and won't give it back to you while the game is running.  You have to alt-tab to select the application you want to focus on - and even when you do, the game is always running.  Meaning you cannot minimize it.  Ever.  The result is that you could be adjusting your controls, remapping keys, and things like that - and while the game is running behind your other programs, things can attack you.  Frustrating as hell.

There doesn't seem to be any way to change keyboard binds.  In fact, I had to go to a third party website just to get a list of keyboard ocmmands.  For some bizarre reason, no such option exists under - options.  

I'm not fond of games that try to pad its "hours of gametime" numbers by making you repeat things over and over.  Especially if you can't control when and where to save the game.  When you do something significant - like get a radio tower working - the game should save it after you zip line to the ground.  Boom.  Saved.  But no.  So if you get killed 10 minutes later, you end up having to do the tower all over again.  That irritates me to no end - because it goes without saying that ANY gamer would know to save their game after fixing a tower.  But this game doesn't want you to.  Instead, it would rather make you do the tower - again - if you die a little later on.  

I mean - the game is big enough on its own.  There's a lot to do, a lot of places to explore, a lot of collectibles to hunt down, enemies to fight,  quests to do, etc.  There's just no need to send a person back to re-do things they finished half an hour ago.   When completing quests, fixing towers, killing bosses - things like that - the game should immediately autosave.  

In most cases, it's a fun game and worth playing.  But since I can't give like ... 3.5 stars and instead I must recommend or not recommend 100% well ... here we are.  It's a pity.

Far Cry 3 - A Mesmerizing Gateway into the Open World Gaming Universe

As a devoted fan of the Far Cry franchise, I eagerly embarked on my journey into the open world gaming universe with Far Cry 3, and oh boy, what an adventure it has been! This game has not only lived up to my expectations as a Far Cry enthusiast but has also solidified my love for open world exploration and thrilling gameplay.

Right from the moment I stepped into the tropical paradise of Rook Island, I was mesmerized by the breathtaking visuals and the immersive world that lay before me. The lush jungles, crystal-clear waters, and sprawling landscapes create an environment that feels alive and brimming with possibilities. Far Cry 3 has set the bar incredibly high for other open world games, and it remains a true masterpiece in its genre.

The narrative of Far Cry 3 is a gripping rollercoaster of emotions. Taking on the role of Jason Brody, a young man stranded on the hostile island, I found myself on a thrilling quest for survival and redemption. The character development is expertly crafted, and I witnessed Jason's transformation from a naive tourist to a fearless warrior, willing to do whatever it takes to save his friends and take down the menacing pirate leader, Vaas. The compelling storyline was like a magnet, drawing me further into the game, eager to uncover every hidden secret of Rook Island.

What sets Far Cry 3 apart from other games in the series is the unparalleled freedom it offers. As a first-time open world gamer, I was in awe of the vastness of the map and the seemingly endless possibilities at my fingertips. From hunting exotic wildlife to liberating enemy outposts, I was given complete autonomy over how I wanted to approach each objective. The game encourages creativity and strategic thinking, making every playthrough a unique and personalized experience.

The gameplay mechanics are smooth and satisfying, with a wide array of weapons and tools at my disposal. Stealthily eliminating enemies from the shadows or engaging in intense firefights never gets old, and the adrenaline rush is unmatched. The skill tree system allows for character customization, making me feel more connected to Jason's progression as I honed my abilities and unlocked new skills.

Aside from the main campaign, Far Cry 3 also boasts an abundance of side quests, activities, and collectibles to explore. Whether it's participating in thrilling races, undertaking hunting challenges, or diving into hidden underwater caves, there's always something new and exciting to discover around every corner. This depth of content ensures that the game's world remains captivating and keeps me coming back for more.

In conclusion, Far Cry 3 is a game that has left an indelible mark on me as a first-time open world gamer and a die-hard fan of the Far Cry series. Its engaging narrative, stunning visuals, and unparalleled freedom of exploration have set the standard for open world games, and it's a journey I would gladly take again and again. If you're a fan of adventure, action, and the thrill of exploring vast open worlds, Far Cry 3 is an absolute must-play that will leave you craving for more of the Far Cry franchise.

Far Cry 3 has a lot of potential, but it is ruined by some poor design choices and disturbing content. The main story forces you to take drugs to advance. I'm not advocating for these missions to be removed from the game. I respect that some players might use recreational drugs, but I wish there was an optional route to finish the story without them.These drug segments are frustrating and tedious to play. 

There is also a scene where you are sexually assaulted by an ally while you are drugged and unconscious, which is never addressed or condemned in the game. Another scene implies that your friend was repeatedly raped by his kidnapper. These are not acceptable themes for a video game, and they make me question Ubisoft‚Äôs ethics as a company. 

The gameplay itself is solid, but it gets repetitive and boring after a while. Many missions are just defending someone from waves of enemies or racing against the clock. The cutscenes are long and unskippable. The later Far Cry games improved on this one in many ways.

Far Cry 3 is an exceptional open-world first-person shooter that delivers an immersive and thrilling gaming experience. From its captivating storyline to its stunning visuals, the game excels in every aspect, making it a standout title in the Far Cry series. 

One of the most commendable aspects of Far Cry 3 is its rich and immersive narrative. The game's storyline is compelling, taking players on a gripping journey of survival and redemption. The well-developed characters, particularly the charismatic and complex antagonist Vaas Montenegro, add depth and intensity to the overall narrative, making it a truly memorable experience.

The game's open-world environment is a masterpiece in itself. The lush tropical setting of Rook Islands is beautifully rendered, offering a vast and diverse landscape for players to explore. The freedom to approach missions and challenges from multiple angles adds a layer of tactical depth to the gameplay, allowing players to embrace their own playstyle and creativity.

Far Cry 3's gameplay mechanics are refined and polished, providing a seamless and enjoyable experience. The fluid combat system, which combines gunplay, stealth, and explosive action, keeps players engaged and on their toes. The variety of weapons, vehicles, and tools at your disposal offer a wide range of strategies, ensuring that no two encounters feel the same.

In addition to its stellar single-player campaign, Far Cry 3 also offers a robust multiplayer mode that provides hours of competitive and cooperative gameplay. Whether teaming up with friends to tackle missions or engaging in intense multiplayer battles, the multiplayer component adds significant replay value to the game.

Overall, Far Cry 3 is a must-play for fans of the FPS genre and open-world exploration. With its engrossing narrative, breathtaking visuals, and engaging gameplay, it sets a high standard for immersive gaming experiences. Step into the shoes of Jason Brody, navigate the perilous Rook Islands, and prepare for an unforgettable adventure that will keep you captivated from start to finish.

This game is one of my favorite PC game experiences ever. It really is as great as they say and I strongly recommend anyone to give it an honest try! The characters are soo well written and the world feels as immersive as that of FC2 (which was a masterpiece at that).
I ran into some really bad bugs, which I think at least half of them had to do with the Ubisoft Launcher and newer ports of the game, which I do not think would take Ubisoft long to patch if they wanted to. Every single launch wanted me to reenter my Ubisoft password, which is very very very unnecessary for a single-player offline game, period.
I also had multiple ctds which really broke my experience because the game telling you "checkpoint reached!" and the launcher telling ypu "saving progress..." are simple lies giving you hope that you do not have to restart a mission from the beginning after watching a minutes-long unskippable cutscene. This was the worst bug I ran into. The actual gameplay is extremely well done and impressed me in a lot of situations where most games would definitely have fallen short.
Another bug is that I could not set my resolution to 4K without really excessive shenanigans, because the game saying "keep options" does not mean horseshit, as they immediately turned down my resolution after exiting. I tried all sorts of things until I realised that I had to alt-f4 my game after changing the resolution  fort it to not turn it back down again after saving my changes.

Still, this game has aged incredibly well and its story and gameplay still make some current AAA games look very old. Well done! I wish there were more games like this. Will try FC4 next...

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

I usually don't review games I haven't played, but this game uses uplay and since i refuse to sign up for yet another DRM based data harvesting  tool I can't play the game I payed for. buy it somewhere drm free if you must, but not here, avoid this version like the plague it is. I feel ashamed I ever spent money on this, it's like finding out I paid someone for painting my house an obnoxious color without my knowledge or approval.

edit: I have since played the game through methods that are legal in france and I'm on the end game island. I usually wait till the end to put my review up, but I don't think they can change my mind with anything new at this point. this game really, really doesn't respect the player's time in the slightest. every fetch quest, every kill quest, every unskippable cutscene, every quest that forces you to use a certain weapon, every quest that railroads you into using stealth, it all adds up to a feeling that these people wanted you to play a diet version of an actual freedom-giving open world game. it's like they desperately wanted to everyone to play the game the same way in a fashion similar to linear games, but people with their head screwed on straight kept forcibly taking them back onto the path of letting people play how they want. 

also again I'm reiterating the cutscenes are unskippable. there's a mod for that now but still, it's an unforgivable sin in my eyes that it needs a mod to fix that in the first place. there's a good game underneath all these horrible design decisions, but for me as an experienced gamer it just feels like I'm playing a version of mercenaries 2 that's bogged down by modern design trends that don't respect the player's time or intelligence and are designed to pad play times instead of give you more content. 

maybe, *hopefully*, the sequels are better but I'm reluctant to try the rest. I'm extra angry I paid for this game now, what the hell was the internet doing getting so hyped over this back in 2012?

Considered the basis of the Ubisoft sandbox formula. After playing later installments it amazes me how they both managed to change so little, yet some annoyances hinder my enjoyment as these things are done better in later installments. Completed the game 100% with stealth only (where possible) on the hardest master difficulty.

Story missions are the easiest in general, solid variety of set-pieces but the meat of the game is the side content. Story is told through brief in-engine cutscenes that are unskippable but do not overstay their welcome. Most of the characters are one-note but fun to interact with. They all have some quotable lines or weird quality in them, except the group you actually supposed to care about. The whole supernatural/spiritual touches with the tribe and tattoo are never really explained but they never purely in the center stage of the plot either, so somehow it works (reminds me of the Indiana Jones movies in that regard). I like how solid they tied the gamey mechanic of a skill tree with the tattoo on your arm. You have 2 endings to pick from depending on a final quest decision.

You dropped into a big island to roam and: 
Hunt animals to skin them and increase your weapon and ammo carry capacity with crafting
There are also specific rule/weapon hunting quests
Activate radio towers with some enjoyable first person platforming to reveal parts of the island map and make weapons free at stores
Do timed race challenges for cash
Clear out enemy outpost by stealth or just going Rambo, they serve as fast travel points afterward
Play some arcade-like, timed, score attack challenge maps where you need to kill infinitely spawning enemies with unique rules/specific weapons and infinite healing/ammo
Do random easy fetch-quests to copy pasted island NPCs where the highlight is usually a silly plot-twist in the end of the scenario
Do stealth/melee kill the specific target missions where the target is usually heavily guarded
Play the f*ckin terrible knife-throwing game to lose a lot of cash
Play poker to waste a lot of time and win back the cash you lost at  the f*ckin knife-throwing game
There are a variety of hidden collectibles you usually have to do some solid platforming to obtain for a small extra xp, these feel like Indiana Jones shorts.

The game pulls a weird "twist" of unlocking a second island when you think it's about to end. This is where it starts to drag on a bit. You ditch all the characters you met so far and it is just you and a new fella from here on. Thankfully it is not the second 50% of the game, there are not much to do on this island. It has less missions on it but traversing is way more tedious thanks to the overkill elevation of terrain on the majority of the island. 
You unlock a wingsuit and parachute but that still requires you to climb to a high point before you can efficiently dive and it never feels like a worthy effort. Fall damage is overtuned, especially on the hardest difficulty, using a kite the landing kills you 99% of the time even if you are above water (might be a bug). Going on foot is tedious but driving vehicles is horrible, the FOV is abysmal and you can just drive off a cliff before you realize the pitfall below, like you roleplay Wile Coyote. The camera shake on a bumpy road is quite intense too.

Stealth in the game is canned animation takedowns, body dragging is only possible after a regular takedown and you cannot pick up bodies once dropped. You got an infinite quantity rock throw distraction item. Enemies can be tagged with your camera to see their position clearly with an icon on them all the time. Silenced weapons are overpowered and if you seek challenge not recommended outside of dealing with the occasional guard dog. Weapons are fine but i find the aim down sight difficult to use on medium distance enemies and below. There are some strange engine related anomalies like character models randomly jitter/shake (insert enemy_soldier.exe stopped working meme) or body dragging suddenly slingshots a corpse up in the air and 20 meter away into a patrol group. These are not game breaking but definitely the worst behavior the game offers, outside of the frequent, random crashing that has no definite solution as far as I know. At least the game autosaves rather frequently.

Ubisoft being themselves not giving a f*ck about preserving their legacy the DLC missions from the deluxe edition cannot be legally obtained anymore but they are actually already in the game data and can be unlocked (Google is your friend). If you are tired of the constant server seeking and error message as you open the game menu then the community fixed that for you too with a basic hex edit, again Ubisoft doesn't bother with such things.

Far Cry III is often praised for its memorable storytelling, writing and innovative gameplay. The game has done many rehauls and improvements to general gameplay, making it more accessible to casual gamers.

Things like fast travel points everywhere, 'claim-it-once-keep-it-forever' pirate outposts scattered everywhere on the map, free guns and equipment, craftable wallets, holsters and bags and many other smaller improvements have "perfected" the casual Far Cry gameplay formula.

The writing is very good, however, it isn't without it's merits. Vaas may be a fucking phenomenal villain, but I can't think of anyone praising Hoyt (or the whole Southern Island, if you ask me). 

All in all, I greatly enjoyed my time with this game. It was very innovative for its time and the game has aged very well since its launch almost ten years ago. 

Old review:
This game is in (almost) every way perfect.

The story is incredibly well written as you can really see how Jason changes as a character after being consumed by the constant insanity of the Rook islands. When he killed someone for the first time, he was in shock, but that shock factor is nonexistent after being brainwashed by the Rakyat and that whore Citra.

The factions (except the privateers) are all well written. The Pirates are scum of the island, robbing and ransoming the local population for a quick buck. They're led by Vaas Montenegro, a man similar to Jason by the end of the game as he too has been consumed by the insanity of the Islands. As you go deeper and deeper into the game, you realize he was right about you. You are me, and I am you.

The Rakyat are the (sorta) better option, however, they brainwash Jason with some sort of dumbass warrior culture, making him a murderer only seeking approval from Citra. Citra is not much better than Vaas, she does the same things he does over and over and over again, but with a different coat of paint. 

Apart from the privateers (which just seem like filler content), this game is very, very well written. You can see how much the Island changed Jason from a South Californian rich white boy to a mass murderer with no remorse for killing people who are so similar to him in many ways. 

The gameplay is a major leap forward compared to FC2. It has shaped the future of Far Cry as IV, V and VI have incredibly similar gameplay formats. FC3 implemented a very beginner friendly system into the world of Far Cry 3. You can fast travel to any location which you've "claimed", claiming outposts is a new thing, making your own wallets, bags and holsters from materials foraged from the Island is a new thing and you can do side content missions around the Island from bulletin boards, but they're pretty.. fucking boring.

The map is very appealing to the eyes. Compared to the gritty, depressing enviroment of Far Cry II, this is a massive godsend. The map is very saturated, tropical and incredibly beautiful. 

All in all, Far Cry III was a massive leap forward for the Far Cry franchise as it introduced many of the features we enjoy in Far Cry IV, V and VI. This is the shining gem of Ubisoft Montreal. Nothing comes close to it

Far Cry 3 is an incredibly unique game, and one of the qualities that makes it stand out is its quotation of the classic line, 'Did I ever tell you what the definition of insanity is?'. It is used throughout the game to great effect, and each time, it serves to remind the player of the character‚Äôs motivations and the underlying themes of the narrative. The quote is used to highlight the repeating cycle of violence the player experiences in their journey, and symbolizes the character's struggle to come to terms with his own sanity. It serves as a warning to the player to think about their decisions in the game, and the repercussions that all their choices carry. Far Cry 3 is an engaging and exciting experience, and its memorable quote is a small part of what makes it so memorable.

It's indispensable in the Far Cry series.  That being said, I wouldn't say it's the best Far Cry game, which is what I was told going into it.
There's some sort of magic stuff in it that is never really acknowledged by any of the characters, which was jarring after the super grounded-in-reality FC2.  It left me looking up what actually happened in a couple scenes or what the silver dragon knife *was* because the line between reality, magic, and drugs got blurred so often.  I feel like in a lot of cases that was the *point*, but ultimately so little actually made sense together or was explained that when the game just... *ends*... I was left feeling like "...that's it?" rather than feeling like I had accomplished any goals or seen the story through to the end.
FC4 also had what felt like a more fleshed-out and less repetitive world, a more interesting and evolving story, and I think was just more enjoyable as a whole.  That's not to say that FC3 is bad in any capacity (other than what I said above), but it's just not as good as it could have been.
As a personal preference, I think Pagan makes a better villain than Vaas - power-hungry and scheming versus just... insane.

In standard game you will have way way too much money; too much because by some astonishingly stupid design decision your wallet is limited in size. If you find yourself out of options as for where to spend your money, then you can buy all possible attachments for all possible guns.

The quest to hunt the critter you need for the largest loot backpack comes from the outpost north of Badtown, if I remember correctly.

Remember to save manually before quitting, in case you had been exploring and not done a mission for a while, which would have autosaved.

There's a skill on the skill tree called Jungle Run that improves your crouched moving speed. Prioritize the stealth skills and health buffs.

It's not explained very well in the game, but use the camera to tag and "wallhack" enemies. It has a longer range to do so than other weapons.

Buy the bow. Use the bow. Love the bow. The bow is probably the best early game weapon, it's silent and you can recover your ammo.

When you get rid of outposts enemy respawns more or less disappear in that area forever. You might see a jeep full of pirates if you're lucky, but they're a lot rarer.

There are only two things you can lock yourself out of. There's a relic (spider #1) in the cave under the doctor's house, and there's a skill you can unlock only if you take two outposts without being detected. Don't worry too much about the latter, since the skill unlocks a long ways into the story and by the end of the game taking out outposts without detection is child's play.

Far Cry 3 is in all likelihood the high water mark of the Far Cry series.  It has that perfect blend of setting, characters, theme and story.  All the numbered Far Cry games that followed have just been refinements on what Far Cry 3 accomplished.  Sure Blood Dragon was an amazing 80s-drenched spin-off and we saw excellently portrayed villains in Pagan Min (Far Cry 4) and the Seed siblings (Far Cry 5). But Far Cry 3 set the standard.  The game plays like when Richard gets exiled from the community in the film The Beach but with a strong dose of Alice In Wonderland meets Heart of Darkness.  You, as Jason Brody, find yourself in the unenviable position of being kidnapped along with your friends and brothers by South Pacific pirates.  You're in a remote, forgotten part of the world so there's no cavalry coming to save you.  You must embrace the warrior within you, go native in a drug- and violence-fueled bender and do whatever it takes to save your friends single-handedly. At first, Jason feels in over his head and is just doing whatever he can to survive but as he grows more skilled and accomplished in his feats he begins to embrace and relish in the savagery he visits upon his foes.  You become something of a living legend among the Rakyat people resisting Vaas' pirates but always find yourself on the knife's edge of sanity as you contend with the rogues gallery of colorful characters in your way.  Everyone loves Vaas and Buck as villains though the game's final act feels a little rushed as Hoyt - the final antagonist - is not given the same opportunity to flourish for the audience.  This causes the final act to feel a *slightly* less satisfying though by this point the game has done its level best to give you a memorable story.  Follow up games, notably 4, feel like the ultimate refinement to the mechanics introduced in this game, and Blood Dragon throws out any semblance of realism for the sake of pure fun by eliminating the annoying but realistic mechanics (no more fall damage, super fast running, no drowning), but this is a well-balanced, well-crafted entry and the superior experience in terms of story, locale, and characters.  If you only play one Far Cry game, let it be this one and embrace the savage beauty of the Rook Islands.

It's kind of surprising just how much of Far Cry 3's gameplay loop was so influential on basically the entire industry now that I'm revisiting it around a decade after its release, for better or for worse. I loved this game back then, but now I feel pretty lukewarm on it at best.

The open world model in Far Cry 3 has barely changed since this game came out. And much like the games that imitate this formula, good lord there is way too much boring shit to do. And I know exactly why it's all so boring, this game is way too easy. Everything is practically handed to the player on a silver platter which makes pretty much all of the rewards for doing said boring shit basically useless. Even the stuff that starts out fun like clearing strongholds quickly feels like a grind when you already have a bottomless source of weapons and ammo after just playing the game for a few hours.

The only resource that actually does matter is xp. Well that and animal hides, but those end up being a lot easier to find than they should be and are mainly used to craft bigger ammo pouches, weapon slots, loot bags, etc. which trivialize combat with how much shit they let you carry so they end up hurting the overall experience more than they help. Anyway, the xp you get from practically every action you can take in this game allows you to buy skills that will either give you better passive stats like health, weapon accuracy, and speed, or you could get new actions you can do like new takedowns, power slides, or using weapons while ziplining. Unfortunately, the skills that give you more mechanical freedom are usually locked behind missions and/or passive skills that I couldn't give less of a shit about getting. And it's not clear to me if it's a certain number of missions, or specific story missions that have to be completed that unlock them. Either way, it's not ideal.

Ironically, not doing all of the boring grindy shit makes the open world a lot more fun to explore. Not clearing strongholds means you're going to run into enemy patrols frequently and will have to sneak your way around them or fight them to get where you need to go. It also means you have no fast travel points and actually have to navigate the dangerous landscape. Not collecting loot or crafting the pouches that give you bottomless weapons and ammo means you have to think hard about what you're gonna bring with you and forces you to seriously consider the value of each bullet used in an engagement. Not turning on the radio towers means you have to rely on your own memory and landmarks to navigate the island.

However to the game's credit, all of the grinding and shit I just complained about actually reinforces the game's narrative and the protagonist's character development. When Jason Brody (spoilers I guess? The following is pretty common knowledge about this game at this point) rescues his friends and they're all like "we almost fucking died or became slaves, why are you so chipper?", it feels believable because all the time I spent before that was crafting weapon holsters out of bear hides and picking off people one-by-one in a jungle like I was Rambo, and I was having fun doing it too. Unfortunately both endings are wet farts to an otherwise pretty decent story with compelling characters even after the best villain is killed off halfway through the game and the primary one after that just appears and doesn't have nearly the charisma.

All this to say, it's fine I guess. This game still looks and sounds pretty and it plays fine. Check it out; or don't if you're not a fan of the formulaic open world games that have been plaguing the industry ever since this game came out because it's patient zero. You have to play through Ubisoft's DRM so you're probably better off getting it through their store, but it's not as intrusive as it used to be from what I remember about trying to play this game when it came out so it isn't the (italics) worst thing in the world to play it through Steam.

Far Cry 3 is very different from all the other Far Crys. You play as a nameless, almost robot like character in Far Cry 5 and New Dawn. In Far Cry 4, you play as a soldier who just does as he is told, Amita and Sabal are both the true villians, not Pagen Min. And even though Ajay has the ability to overthrow them both, he doesn't. But Far Cry 3, it shows you your everyday tourist, but as life pushes him, farther and farther. Jason turns into a monster. Slaughtering people without second thought, his own friends see this in him. And even Vaas, the deranged lunatic, sees this in Jason too. The character development in Far Cry 3 is what makes it so much better than all of the other Far Crys. Next time you play it, think as yourself as the villian, the monster. Let me begin by saying that this game is truly something else. I love everything about it. Two very important elements set Far Cry 3 apart from nearly every other FPS out there, those elements being story and gameplay. I'll start off with the story. It starts off as your typical B action movie but eventually changes into something completely unexpected that is less cliched and more unique.

The game's primary focus in the beginning is to guide you with saving your friends from some goofy pirates but the plot thickens as your character begins exploring some dark and very uncomfortable realms. That's where the element of gameplay comes in. The open world game provides the player with a plethora of weapons and tools that can be used to aid with taking out enemies, hunting wild animals, and exploring two beautifully designed tropical islands.

I remember playing this game in 2012, and it being an amazing game. Fast forward a little over 10 years later and i can say for certain that this game stood the test of time.

The gameplay is very simple, yet allows for a lot of flexibility for how you approach things. The Master difficulty is difficult (but not overly difficult,), and is my personal preference because it made me actually think about how i'm going to do something before i charge in and make my life 10x harder. It also encourages you to do the side missions to get stronger in order to have an easier time later on down the road. Not to mention the crafting system is really well done, you may not want to spend time crafting wallets, or loot rucksacks, or anything else, but you'll find yourself in a position where you'll be thinking "hey, before i do this mission i should either A) Craft a bigger thing so i can hold more of that thing, or B) Spend / exhaust this thing so i can pick up / collect more down the road.

The story is very good, but nothing mind-blowing. However, what caught my eye wasn't the story itself but how the protagonist and the people around him react to his actions and his behavior down the road. There are a few well placed jokes / comedic relief moments which is surprisingly fitting when they happen, but overall it's a very well put together game that i highly recommend playing at least once, even if you just speed through the story. It makes you surprisingly engaged, even if you want to just go around slaughtering anyone and everyone

Overall, i'd give this game a strong 9/10, for the time that it was released i'd say it definitely delivered to the players. The graphics are pretty decent, Gameplay can be challenging and rewarding (while also making you do other things to make life easier), and the flexibility in playstyle preference definitely make this game worthy of the rank.

As far as the game itself, it holds up over time to an extent, but it's a lot of the same so far, mainly hunting to be able to hold more items in backpacks and more guns/ammo. Someone told me before I played this or Far Cry 5 that it doesn't matter which you play first, and I guess I agree. I liked FC5 quite a bit, so it motivated me to go ahead and binge that game until I beat it, but now coming to a game made 7+ years earlier, it requires a bit more patience to play on. I wonder if I would've enjoyed playing this one first as a result, but I think I would've just gotten bored with it and jumped to FC5 anyway, then not bouncing back to this one. So yeah, for anyone buying the two together in the DLC, I'd start with 5 and, if you like it enough, come back to 3. Hopefully it gets more interesting once the story develops a bit more.

As far as the interface, it's absolutely terrible. Every time you want to craft something new, you have to go to the menu (which has this whole slow animation), then click another 4 more things. Every time you want to USE something you've crafted, same thing (unless it's one of the TWO that you've assigned to a hotkey). It's absurd that the only thing in this game that has a hotkey is 'M' for map. No inventory, no skills, no anything. It's the worst interface that I've seen since probably the 90s. I don't know what they were thinking.

Update: As I near the end of the game, I can say that the story's pretty good, and it has some injected trippy points in the later half that are definitely cool‚Äîand considerably trippy considering how long ago it was made‚Äî[spoiler]though I guess they weren't sure how to execute boss battles because there basically aren't any. I was disappointed by the "battle" with Vaas, even less of a battle with Hoyt. Neither were satisfying at all. I was impressed with FC5's boss battles; they had figured it out by then.[/spoiler] My favorite part of the game winds up being the semi-smart AI enemies, which provides a challenge, especially when you can't kill them and need to sneak around them. I did have to increase the difficulty up to the third level, I think it's called "Warrior." Especially in the middle of the game if you have access to the big guns/better items because of more looting (I'm an OCD loot everything freak), it can get pretty easy. Later in the game it does account for the player having better items and picks up in difficulty though. In a good way.

Last Update: Weak ending. Not bad, per se, but not at all the kind of thorough ending you want after putting over 100 hours into a game. Having now beaten it, I'm pretty sure my time could've gone towards something more enjoyable. Oh well.

All in all, if not for the pretty good story and gameplay, I wouldn't be able to play it at all.

one of the best Far Cry games all around.

for those of you who dont know. Far cry 3 feels like an improved version of the far cry console games, ( instincts/predator) but handled way better...

no it is not the same story, only game play elements are fixed up. such as the ability to craft syringes that do different effects. speed, strength, scent, jump, all that fun stuff.... as well as crafting to make your guy stronger. from crafting more holsters for guns, or ammo pouches to carry more max ammo.

the map is also handled differently. in original far cry, and console versions... its a linear game with multiple pathways to get to the goal..... far cry 3 on the other hand, is open world. you can go where ever you want on the giant north island, taking outposts and the like on your own terms, making the game flow much easier.

lots of side quests, and the one thing its known for........Radio towers. which at the time were new to the far cry series, but also annoying. ( there not that bad, each tower you climb different, and opens up a section of map to view.

sadly, UPlay no longer is active, so there are alot of things missing now. such as the co-op seperate campaign which is interesting.

sadly, where they fell short was multiplayer overall compared to far cry instincts and predator. for example, you can still create custom maps, and move the world terrain however you like..... but the biggest difference is that in far cry 3 multiplayer, there are no vehicles, and thats a real big missed opportunity, the former had all vehicles in multiplayer, making for some real interesting maps and concepts.

this game also was the one to introduce parachutes, and wing suits...... both perks you get way later in the game.

all in all far cry 3 has been a fav of mine for a long time. and if you havnt checked it out, i still strongly suggest doing so. ( or any of the far cry games. ) If you want to experience a different setting if far cry, check out either far cry: primal, or far cry blooddragon.

primal is cave man farcry.... blooddragon however is a farcry in game movie, turned into a video game..... and its ridiculous in all the right ways.

I am a 777 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 2 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

In Far Cry 3, you play as Jason Brody, a college student who somehow becomes a one-man army after his island vacation goes horribly wrong. By "horribly wrong," I mean he gets kidnapped by a band of pirates, meets a crazy drug lord, and becomes a warrior who can somehow heal bullet wounds by eating a handful of berries.

The real star of the show: Vaas. This guy is like the Joker if he was a drug-addicted pirate with a mohawk. He is the kind of villain who will monologue about the definition of insanity while you are trying to sneak past his goons, and then he will shoot you in the face just for fun.

The gameplay is a blast, too. You can climb radio towers to reveal more of the map, hunt exotic animals to craft better equipment, and liberate enemy outposts to unlock fast travel points. There are also trippy drug sequences that make you feel like you are in a music video.

The game can sometimes take itself a little too seriously. There is a part where you have to burn a field of marijuana plants while Skrillex plays in the background. It is like they are trying to make a statement about the War on Drugs or something.

Far Cry 3 is a wild ride that will make you feel like a badass action hero...as long as you can suspend your disbelief and ignore the fact that you are playing as a trust fund kid who somehow knows how to handle a grenade launcher.

The only Far Cry I played before this was FC1 on the original Xbox, so Ubisoft's now mass-produced open-world collect/climbathon FPS thing was a new experience for me. Further, I'm accounting for the game's age in my comments below. I'd prefer to leave a mixed review for the ups, downs and baffling design decisions, but there were a few issues below I just couldn't get past. I know I'm in the minority, but having since played FC4 and 5, I'll never go back to 3.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
+Good graphics
+Good voice acting
+Lots of in-game tutorials and guides
+Tons to do if you're a completionist
+Gunplay is fun
+Minimal opening splash screens
+Fast travel
+Relatively stable (1 softlock in about 50 hours of play)
+DLC integrated into main game
+Save anywhere and no real penalty for dying

[h1]YMMV[/h1]
~Ubisoft open-world repetitive collectathon gameplay

~One villain is occasionally interesting, but disappears too soon

~A few mandatory poker minigames, but they seem to be guaranteed wins

~Alice in Wonderland quotes came off as pretentious

~Not a single likable character in the game for any length of time. When playing FC4, I gave myself whiplash from approval nodding after Willis (himself one of the biggest jerks in the series) called Jason Brody a "SoCal douchebag".

~Besides the well-represented first kill, I don't see all the protagonist character development frequently lauded in the game. He's an idiot from start to finish. Further, being KO'd more than a narcoleptic boxer does not constitute character development. It's too bad he didn't stop griping about skinning animals, or that he didn't handle weapons clumsily at the start. These would have fit well into his [spoiler]increased love of violence[/spoiler].

~The game's pretty gritty. Expect foul language, frequent drug use, visceral first-person violence, physical and sexual slavery of all ages and genders, and [spoiler]a crowning rape scene with topless nudity. Now, I know most players won't be offended because, like in Alpha Protocol, the apparent victim is a guy who doesn't complain, and the perp is a busty female. Buuuut, let's be realistic: having sex with someone after drugging them is straight-up nonconsensual. The fact that the perp and her cronies are otherwise grooming the victim for service in a manner very similar to how Hitler groomed the SS just makes it skeezy[/spoiler].

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
-POS Ubisoft Connect launcher and Denuvo
-Store description of purchase options vague. Needlessly hard to set up.
-DLC etc didn't automatically add to my account
-Quicktime events using random buttons was a literal killer on KB&M
-Wingsuit causes death more often than not
-Animals are bullet-sponge, OP jerks that cause more deaths than anything else
-Boar skins are way too hard to find for an essential early crafting recipe
-Menu system is cumbersome at best
-Fall damage very inconsistent, even with skill that reduces it
-Looting items is a chore
-Easy to max out money, making collecting impossible in some cases
-Tons of misspellings and minor to moderate bugs, requiring reloads
-Second half of game in particular is buggy as sh!t

Played on:
i7-4790, GTX1060, 16GB RAM
KB&M
Normal difficulty

[i]3/22/2023 - This is one of my oldest reviews that uses my outdated format, I no longer make use of this format.[/i]

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
I am Tigerfrost. I would like to apologize for anything that is miss-spelled or any grammar issues. Thank you.
If you'd like to skip straight to Pro's & Con's, please move to the bottom of the page. Thank you.

[h1]How I Found Out About "Far Cry 3"[/h1]
Well, where to start. To put it simply, I rented Far Cry 3 on the Ps3 a little while after it came out. After it's release, weeks went by, as I heard more and more about Far Cry 3. Nothing was spoiled, but I heard so many good things about it. At the time, I really didn't have the money, so I decided to rent the game, like I use to do back in the day.

After picking up the game, I was able to play through about half of it, before needing to take it back. However, around Christmas, my parents got me Far Cry 3 on the Ps3 and I was able to finish my adventure.

About six months after that, I saw the Deluxe Edition of Far Cry 3 on sale on Steam, and picked it up. Then things became really good. 

[h1]Unfair FIrst Impressions[/h1]
Every game genre gets hate by some people. Mainly because of opinions, which is okay. There are genre' I don't like, and others I do. However, the main thing I see about Far Cry 3 in reviews that give it a low score is.....Uplay. Why, oh why must you give the [b]GAME[/b] a bad score because it uses Uplay? I understand, it's annyoing at times, especially needing to run it through two different clients, but to give the game itself a bad score because it uses Uplay, is very unfair. I have never had any problems running Far Cry 3 through both Steam & Uplay. Basically, when it says someone is playing Far Cry 3 on Steam, they actually have their Uplay open, as the game itself doesn't need to be running to say you're actually in-game.

Not to mention, Far Cry 3 has crafting in it, along with survival tactics. Someone went as far to report the game for being a Minecraft clone because of it. 

[h1]Review Of "Far Cry 3"[/h1]
Far Cry 3 is an [b]open world[/b], [b]first person shooter[/b], [b]survival type[/b] game. With a very in depth story. Good and memorable characters. Amazing world, and game mechanics. 

The game takes you in the shoes of "Jason Brody", a rich kid who takes a vaction to an island with a group of friends. Before having enough time to enjoy themselves, Jason and his friends find themselves captured by pirates ruled by "Vass". It's Jason's job to break out of the slave camp and get his friends back. Having never shot or killed anyone, it is up to you to learn how to take down your foe using a wide variety of weapons. Using drugs made off of plants from the jungle, and working alongside people like Denis. Can you make it happen?

Far Cry 3 allows you to form your story. Everyone's playthrough will be different. 

The world of Far Cry 3. The world is massive. In my Just Cause 2 review, I talked about the world being massive, but mostly empty. Here, the world is not only massive, it isn't empty. Everywhere there is something to collect, capture, destroy, hide from, or [b]DIE[/b] from. The world is split between two islands, which take part at different sections of the story. Each lush with plains, jungle's , a lot of killer animals, green, some more green, beautiful oceans and caves. Far Cry 3 is a graphically intense looking game. The views are just amazing. The world is populated by loot, like weapons, money, and relics. There are also deadly animals, like the Tiger, or Cassowary. Not only that, pirates, who only mean to kill you. 

Far Cry 3 does it nicely, where the whole game isn't out to kill you. The pirates will get into fights with the natives. Angry animals will attack civilians, and pirates. You could sit at a far, watching through the scope of a sniper rifle, as a Tiger slips through the enemy defense and takes down a group. 

Thrown about this world are these plants. These plants can be used to craft drugs to help you with many things. Like detecting animals, or increasing maximum health, etc. Along with crafting drugs, you can also craft other items. Like wallets to carry more money, weapon holsters to carry more weapons, or munitions pouch to carry more grenades. One thing that's strange about this is the fact that you must skin animals to craft these. However, for one thing you might need 2 Tiger skin, and the next, 1 Deer skin, see my problem with this?

Scatered around the world are [b]strongholds[/b] or "outposts" that are controlled by the pirates. You can take these down by killing all pirates on the inside. By capturing one of these strongholds, it makes the territory around you safe, and creates a fast travel system. Now, how you approach these strongholds to take them down is all up to you. You have full freedom to do what you want. You could run right in with heavy machine guns blazing it out. You sit from a far with a sniper rifle and pick them off. You could sneak in, perform takedowns and use a stealth recurve bow. Or you could lure an animal into the base. There are so many things you could do. 

To take down these strongholds, you need weapons, right? Worry no more. The weapons provided in Far Cry 3 consist of pistols, SMG's, Assault rifles, snipers, shotguns, HMG's, flare gun's, flame throwers, and way more.

Now, while on a mission, though they provide a good story, you are restricted most of the time. Meaning you can't really approach the way you may want to. 

Alongside the main story, you of course have side missions. These are of two types, but work and are fun. The first of them being the Hunter missions. Where you take out an animal for various reasons. The second being the Wanted Dead missions, where it is your job to take down a baddie with your knife/machete. 

You also earn XP for getting kills and completing missions. XP will gain you skill points, which then lead to you choosing a skill you'd like. One problem with this system is, you don't have access to all the skills until you get futher into the story. As the skills move on, they get kind of more useless. However that's just my opinion.

If there is really anything else I don't care about in this game, it's that the second half falls short of the first half. It doesn't really keep the hype going, it kind of dies down. 

[h1]Thoughts (Other)[/h1]
I'd like to post this here. Far Cry 3 is so far my most favorite single player experience of all time. The story was great, the gameplay was great. The soundtrack is amazing, and brings man tears. This was one of the best things I have ever played. Now a days, I use a hardcore mod. Mods are available for Far Cry 3 that can fix things, or make the game more realistic and hard. Now, obviously Far Cry 3 being my favorite, I cannot wait for the release of Far Cry 4 which only comes in a couple weeks. I cannot WAIT.

[h1]Pro's & Con's (Overall Rating)[/h1]
Far Cry 3 is a great game that is well worth the time. For the story, the world, and the gameplay. Every piece of this game is full of greatness. You ability to do what you want beings a new level to video games. We need more, like this.

Pro's:
+Amazing story.
+Great memorable characters.
+Beautiful world that's full of life.
+Great weapon mechanics.
+Fantastic gameplay.
+Big populated open world.

Con's:
-Second half of game falls a little short.
-Some of the crafting is strange.
-Skill tree could use a little work.

Overall Rating: About a 14/15 (Must Own!)

Far Cry 1 was the game that changed the FPS genre, Far Cry 2 laid the groundwork for the rest of the Far Cry franchise, but it was Far Cry 3 that launched the series into the limelight

I started Far Cry 3 comparing it with it's successor (Far Cry 4).
This mindset lead me to point out tons of flaws in the game: no auto-drive, grappling hook or wingsuit, parachute (which was how Jason found himself in Rook Island). I had none of the additional stealth options like beehives, throwing knives and only 1 bow. The vehicle handling felt a bit off, with no shooting allowed. With FC3 being set in 2012 (only 2 years before the events of FC4), the lack of a Buzzer or even Hovercraft felt limiting when traversing the world.

Certain quests seemed to ignore some of the "rules" that have been set so far; an example being the quest "A Man Named Hoyt" where you are tasked to remain undetected, where shooting a lone enemy would instantly fail the mission, but take-downs were allowed.

Of course, this didn't mean that I didn't enjoy many of the other features that the game had to offer.
You have access to one of the strongest sniper rifles in the game pretty early on (the AMR), making it quite easy to stay a safe distance away, whilst picking off even the toughest of enemies.
The threat of falling right off a radio tower often had my heart pounding in my throat, whilst also allowing a little reprieve from the blood-shed
The variety of syringes brought along some neat tactics.
Then there are the animals: RHINOS are gone; eagles... gone; devil fish.. gone. There is also quite a significant variety, making crafting a fun side-quest to pursue and complete quite early on. Even if you don't set out to pursue it, the Path of the Hunter missions line up nicely with completing all inventory packs and holsters.
The open ocean did mean that almost drowned Jason a few times by just trying to explore for a bit and take in the beauty, with turtles and manta rays swimming about.  And let's not forget about sharks.  THERE WERE SHARKS!

When the wingsuit is unlocked, I would specifically run up cliffs just to fly down.
With how little game-time crocodiles had in FC4, seeing a crocodile for the first time sparked some joy. Even though I wouldn't dive into the swampy rivers without using a Hunter's Instinct Syringe.  Even wingsuit-diving into rivers would have my heart racing... Sadly crocs were not done much justice here either.

The first half of the story felt a little dull compared to Sabal's and Amita's struggles in Kyrat, and I would not call the second half a Tim Burton masterpiece either, but the sense of a more personalised story line was a good change of pace compared to fighting in what felt like "someone else's war", for a purpose that you are end up feeling guilty for regardless of your choice (Sabal or Amita).
The second half also unlocked a few of those missing features from before, making the final hours a lot of fun, even to a point where that it might be enough motivation that FC5 and after may just be added to my library before long.

The gameplay is fun, but the story's terribly short and rather mediocre. 

The game's length comes primarily from doing side missions, whereas if you focused on main quests, the game wouldn't be very long really at all. The side missions are also incredibly repetitive too. You only have three: Hunt animal, kill specific person with a knife, and capture outposts.

Capturing outposts is kind of a negative though, because it means the island becomes safer and you are engaging less and less often with the enemy. Plain and simply, it gets boring wandering a vast island with no one to fight at all. You have all these weapons, and the most you'll use them on are the animals around you who target you like you're a big red flag with the words "kill me" written on it. 

A thing I don't like about this game is that it rewards you for being stealthy. Like, TOO much. 

Go aggressive, and you get 500 XP. No alarms triggered, you get 550 XP. 
Go stealthy, you get 1500 XP. That's 1k more XP, and the bonus XP you get from headshotting (20) is NEVER going to add up to the amount you get from going purely stealthy. 

Also, takedowns reward LOADS of XP. Kill this big ol' guy here, 750 XP. Chain a few kills, gain hundreds of XP, quickly and easily. It's crazy how much you get. 

Also, I don't really get why, but they let you have access to almost every single craftable item from the start of the game. Right out of the gate, you can go hunt, craft, and upgrade, each and every item in the game to their second-to-highest level, with the only thing stopping you being rare items only found on mission-specific animal hunts. 

The sense of growth and progression is ruined for the entirety of the rest of the game. You've already gotten pretty much as strong as you can possibly get, there's nothing the game can do anymore to make you actively feel like you're progressing toward anything at all. 

Also, I hate how the game handled its weapons. 

There are just "best weapons", in each category. There's no reason to use X, Y, or Z weapon, when W (or T) weapon, does the exact same thing but better in every way. I don't even understand why this is a problem games have to begin with, stop putting all of these weapons in the game if they're completely and utterly useless against its competition with zero special case uses to justify even having it in the first place.

Vaas is a great villain, and a great character, but the protagonist becomes a pretty unlikable character quickly. He's turning insane, but it's done in just such an unlikable manner that he seems more like an @sshole than an insane person. The rate at which he turns insane is unnaturally fast too, which makes it weird and awkward that over the course of a few days he just suddenly barely gives a single shit about any of his friends and just wants to kill people.

Far Cry 3 is a game that offers players an immersive and thrilling gaming experience. Set on a beautiful, yet dangerous tropical island, the game places players in the role of Jason Brody, a young man who finds himself stranded on the island after a vacation gone wrong. With the island teeming with pirates and other dangerous creatures, Jason must fight for survival and rescue his friends from their captors.

One of the standout features of Far Cry 3 is its open-world gameplay. Players are free to explore the island at their leisure, uncovering hidden secrets, and taking on side missions along the way. The game's stunning visuals and immersive sound design bring the island to life, creating an atmosphere of danger and excitement that keeps players engaged and on edge.

The combat in Far Cry 3 is fast-paced and intense, with a wide range of weapons and tactics available to players. The game's skill tree system allows players to customize their character's abilities, making it possible to tailor their gameplay experience to their personal preferences. The game's AI is also impressive, with enemies reacting realistically to the player's actions and tactics.

The story in Far Cry 3 is well-written and engaging, with memorable characters and a compelling narrative. The game's themes of survival, revenge and redemption add depth and emotional weight to the gameplay, making it a satisfying and fulfilling experience from beginning to end.

Overall, Far Cry 3 is an exceptional game that offers players an unforgettable gaming experience. Its open-world gameplay, stunning visuals, intense combat, and engaging story make it a must-play for fans of the first-person shooter genre. If you're looking for a thrilling and immersive gaming experience, Far Cry 3 is worth checking out.

I'm glad I picked this game up - because I won't have to play any more Far Cry games after this. If this is what widely considered the "peak" of the franchise, the rest is just downhill, right?

I love Michael Mando from Better Call Saul, and what little time we got to spend with him in-game as Vaas is actually quite compelling, but he is literally the only interesting character. (SPOILER) You'd think with his face plastered on every piece of marketing material, you'd at least get to fight the guy for real, not another damned QTE.

For a game that prides itself in the transformation of its protagonist, Jason Brody's journey lacks subtlety, compounded by lackluster voice acting.

I love this game, and it's an easy recommendation, but having to deal with the shitty Ubisoft launcher and figuring out how to make the game work was one of the worst PC gaming experiences I have ever had, and don't get me started as to why the game doesn't have achievement even thought the game has achievement on the launcher, and having to enter my password every time I try to play the game.

Having played and finished Far Cry and Far Cry 2, I was looking forward to Far Cry 3.

And although it's many years old, it was a buggy mess compared to the other two.
They weren't perfect, but at least they tried.

Issues
- Ubisoft Connect requiring me to sign in EVERY TIME I want to play.
- Far Cry 3 Online trying to connect, failing, and interrupting everytime I press pause on reload.
- Hard crashes mid mission causing me to have to redo it all
- No saving mid mission
- Using the Loot button to be the same as replace weapon
- Weird Zoom bug 
- Switching to the sniper rifle after planting a bomb in a mission, even though I had another weapon equipped

Additionally, some questionable design decisions (I played in Hard Mode, so take it with a grain of salt)
- Predator animals hanging around RIGHT OUTSIDE a safe area, causing you to get instantly mobbed
- No indication of more unlockable weapons coming up, causing one to perhaps waste money after unlocking everything mid game
- Awkward fade to black between cutscenes
- Field of view not kept in ingame cutscenes and climbing ladders, causing a nauseating zoom out effect at the end of these

And many more small irritations.

I ended up finishing the game due to sunk cost fallacy and because it is still a fun experience, but I expected much more, and I can't understand how this game was so successful.

FAR CRY 3 review (consoles XBOX 360 PS3 Windows PS4 XBOX ONE) 

Far Cry 3 is an open world first person shooter game developed and published by ubisoft released in 2012 the game recieved critical acclaim prasing its island setting amount of content gameplay and story
in my opinion this game is one the best games i ever played 

Visuals :the game looks great with great lighting great foliage design and the enviroments are bright vibrant hiding the terrible things that is going on in the islands and they immerse me in the world

Sound : the sound is great with a great sundtrack and some absolutely fantastic voice acting from michael mandos performance as vaas who truly feels insane 

gameplay the game is designed as a first person shooter set in an open world called the rook islands the islands are beautiful with so much wildlife the wildlife has everything from crocodiles sharks to deer tigers and monkeys the world truly feels alive and the animals act extremely realistically and aggresively the animals hunt other animals and it feels like every animal is going to attack you it really boosts the tension because you dont know whats gonna happen next the 2nd island doesnt unlock until you get further the story missions are linear with only one way to complete the only choices is during the ending there is a lot of side activities 

1-Outposts: outposts are territories that you can take over from enemy soldiers the outposts are all non linear with lots of ways to go through them you can do assault or go stealth once you takeover an outpost it becomes a fast travel point once you takeover all of the outposts you can restart the outposts and do them all over again

2-supply drop: you must drive through markers on a quad bike to deliver medical supllies

3-Path of the Hunter: a poth quest is unlocked after taking over an outpost you have to hunt a rare animal and skin it to unlock the highest tiers of crafting equipment

4-trials of the rakyat: you have to gun through waves of enemy troops within a time limit with a fixed set of weapons

5-wanted dead: find a pirate commander and take him out with a 
specific kind of weapon

6-poker: just straight up poker

7-radio towers: climb all of the radio towers and make the map more visible climbing radio towers also gives you free weapons making you want to climb all of them

8-map editor: there is a map editor for far cry 3 and its not as complex as later entries map editors but you can still make really cool maps with it but the map editor is not available on the ps4 and xbox one versions

pros 
1-great visuals
2-fun and challenging combat
3-lots of activities
4- awesome story and characters
5- great soundtrack and voice acting 
6- awesome world to explore
7- lots of awesome guns 

cons
1- the framerate on ps3 and xbox 360 is not that good it runs at 25 fps mostly but on ps3 its incredibly laggy after a patch its still laggy this game is really pushing these consoles to the limit 
2- there is no map editor or multiplayer on xbox one and ps4

this game is great with lots of content beautiful visuals and an indepth storyline

Far Cry 3 follows on from Far Cry 2 with a more conventional open world, more activities, collectibles, and a return to a tropical island. And the definition of crazy.

[/b]The Story[b]
I quite enjoyed the story of FC3. I did not come into this game blind, I knew the over arching plot of the game but I was still nicely entertained by the cutscenes and some fun bombastic moments. 
Vass is a pretty nice villain and is probably One of the most iconic in this series. The secondary villain though, was a dissapointment, he's not bad but he doesn't have the same presence and character entertainment value that Vass does.
The cutscenes are very well animated with good voice acting to support. A change from the previous entry is the fact that the cutscenes are actual cutscenes and not just the characters simply facing in your general direction and sound coming out.
It's not the most complex story, the characters start off a little dumb, but I found it quite enjoyable in the end.


[/b]The Graphics:[b]
Far Cry 3 looks decent, there‚Äôs a definite upgrade in lighting and texture quality over the Far Cry 2. The only problems I had with the presentation of the game is that the far blur and the ambient occlusion effects are too strong. Other than that the game looks great for what it is. 
I used the Far Cry 3 Redux mod to remove the far blur and change the ambient occlusion effect. It also changed some of the UI to make it less cluttery, which I found to be a nice change.
I also used reshade.
Optimization wise, the game ran well on max settings both unmoded and moded.

[/b]The Audio:[b]
The audio is fine. Generally, I found the soundtrack to not be particularly memorable (I had to reinstall the game just to remember what it sounded like).  Character audio though sounds great and the voice acters do a good job. Gun sounds are also nice and since audio is important in gameplay to find enemies the mixing is also good.
[/b]The Gameplay:[b]
Far Cry 3 is imo, the first game in this series that feels and plays like the stereotypical Ubisoft open world; the towers, the map revealing, the outposts, its all there but its not as boring as it sounds because a lot of the busy work is optional but the map revealing and the towers actually provide a benefit in revealing the map and reducing the amount of enemies so that you can focus on the main campaign or whatever else you want to do.
My playstyle for this game was stealth backed up by fire as the fire spreading in this game is great and a little bit op.
I did only about 3 of the side missions but focused mainly on the campaign missions.

[/b]Overall:[b]
I liked Far Cry 3, the game was pretty fun and the story kept me going without much trouble or loss of interest. Game still looks pretty decent and hasn‚Äôt aged too badly in 2022. 

[/b]Tips:[b]
-	Fire is friend
-	Far Cry 3 Redux mod is pretty good.

The first Far Cry released in 2004 got me hooked on the series.  All the Far Cry games are first person shooters set in an open world.  I also loved how they themed each one based on a classic novel.  I'm actually going to rate all of them and list the books, I think they are inspired by:
2004 - Far Cry (The Island of Doctor Moreau, 1896, H. G. Wells) - VERY GOOD
2008 - Far Cry 2 (Heart of Darkness, 1899, Joseph Conrad) - BETTER
2012 - Far Cry 3 (Alice's Adventures in Wonderland, 1865, Lewis Carroll) - BEST!
2014 - Far Cry 4 (At first I thought maybe The Man Who Would Be King, 1888, Rudyard Kipling, but now I don't have a clue.) - SECOND BEST
2018 - Far Cry 5 (Don't think it took any book as it's theme) - Disappointing
2021 - Far Cry 6 - haven't played

Bottom Line:  Far Cry 3 used to be the best of the whole lot then Ubisoft stopped supporting the server.  Which means it will constantly try to log on but be unable so you've got that constant delay.  Worst of all, the some of the best parts of the DLC for this game are no longer available as they were accessed on the server.  So I've paid for them but no longer have access to them.  I originally recommended this one but now I recommend you just forget about it and play FarCry 4 instead.  Beautiful setting, engaging protagonist, best ever antagonist.  Great story and excellent characters you meet along the way.  The problem is this game has an expiration date and it has expired. Super disappointing.

Far Cry 3 has all the worst tropes of shitty open world game design.

The game starts off strong story-wise with a great hook and plot setup. 
This is also where you meet Vaas for the first time, played by Michael Mando who is a terrific actor.
Vaas is the leader of a pirate cartel that is in control of the island and you will have multiple encounters with him throughout a playthrough where his mentally insane and psychotic actions are on full display.

These moments are without a doubt this game's biggest strength.

now for the bad stuff, the story is super linear. the main goal is to rescue your captured friends and escape the island. 
I feel like the open world would be a great way to make a personal choice on who to rescue first but that's not possible unfortunately. The island itself is uninteresting to look at and lacks any meaningful landmarks to peak my interest in exploring. There are no meaningful rewards for exploration, the best guns can be bought from a merchant, and animal locations are shown on the map. the whole island has these copy and pasted favelas, radio towers and bunkers that all look the same. The same 2 side missions are copy and pasted everywhere ( hunt animal & kill commander). Guns feel pretty basic and the enemies will sometimes dodge incoming bullets in unrealistic manners just to artificially inflate your engagement with them.

two thirds through the game you "take care" of Vaas but with the main antagonist missing the last portion of the game becomes a real letdown.

At the end of the story, there is a choice to make; stay on the island with the locals or escape from the island with your friends. This choice feels unwarranted with the way the story is presented.

MY PERSONAL STORY WITH FARCRY 3:
I first played this game when I was about 16. I used to work at our family's tiny convenience store. I had a PC with a Pentium processor, 4 GB of ram, and gt 730 2 GB DDR3. This was my first own PC that I built with my own money, I did not have a lot of money back then.

So anyways I had nothing to do and my parents forced me to work then, not that I was against it. I was okay with it because it was summer, and I would be even more bored alone at home watching anime. So, one day I went to buy a new game at our local pirate SD store that had everything, Movies, Games, Music, and Anime. I remember from the internet and some people that this game was good and that it had a very good crazy villain, I remember exactly what I said to the store guy "I want a game with a crazy villain" the store guy found this game for me and I bought it.

This game was perfect for me because I could pause it at any time and help the customers when they entered our store. I paused this game more than 1000 times because whenever I played, a customer would enter, and I would pause. Then they would leave, then another would enter. So I would play for about 5 minutes until the next customer) Of course, there were 1 hour non-stop plays because nobody would enter sometimes.

But this never ruined my experience. It would end up just extending my enjoyment of the game. So there it was a game that had everything I wanted, exploration, fucking amazing story, replayability, and life lessons. This was it, I found the game I would play for 4 months. I found my masterpiece, FARCRY 3. 
This game changed my whole life. This is not an oversaturation, I will explain shortly. First of all, This helped me to move away from the suicidal thoughts I had back then which were very frequent. I was distracted from my problems and I was excited about something in my life again, even if my excitement was just a game. FARCRY gave me a reason to wake up every morning with the only goal to go to work so I can play this game. I consider it a great help to my life. 
Secondly, some lessons from the game were very helpful to me at that time, especially Dennises words:
"We spend our whole lives holding back. Imagine you can succeed if you just take what you want"
This fucking blew my mind, It cut me soo deep that holy shit it was something so deeply personal to me. This, later on, would help me to start learning the English language. Yes, I played FARCRY 3 in Russian first time. But it does change anything. Anyways, those powerful words were an inspiration for me to finally act on the problems and causes of stress in my life at the time. I finally did something I was thinking of doing a long time ago but was afraid of doing. I do that to this day. But I will not tell what exactly, this is the thing only I must know. 
So yes this game is something  I will never forget, It's a good memory and good inspiration, and because of that, I bought it on steam once I could afford it. Thank you to all the wonderful people who worked to create this masterpiece.

Regardless of how many hours it shows I played on steam. My actual hours are much greater. You can just add +800 hours to the current one and it would be more or less correct.
