This game is just the golden treasure of oldschool days and making Far Cry 3 the biggest pot out there. Gunplay, the feeling of wandering around the tropical island full of dangerous animals to hunt which never gets old with its exotic and fun activities, the beautiful scenery and gazes to glance upon. But we all know the main star here is the antagonist none other than Vaas himself. I'll get to that in a moment- but pretty much the game ages well with the only exception of few things.

Screw. Ubisoft launcher. Seriously. Additionally it's odd how achievements from Xbox version didn't make it into here other than existing inside Ubisoft system itself but nobody honestly cares about the launcher other than knowing it's exhausts you very fast from mentioning non-stop how you're not connected to the servers.
Now there are few bugs and glitches here and there especially how enemies penetrate you through some obstacles or even from losing sight from an enemy Sniper but still shoots you behind an object or so. And more to say that exist but it's still doable to ignore these on hardest difficulty for preference being.
I feel like the biggest and yet saddest part is that when Vaas is out of the way, the game feels... boring without him. I'm not saying other antagonists and all were bad or anything it's just the pizzazz and feel wears off. I mean Vaas himself is everywhere especially on the cover of the game. The finale part is boring as it goes. And sad to say that I stopped caring afterwards for the plot being linear and main protagonist being as boring as it can be... not to mention ending choices being extremely stale. I mean heck, even the collectibles just give you tropes and info about the island but no rewards to reap other than for cash and XP boost for starting levels. 

But everything else was enjoyable. If you want to hunt animals, glide, drive, assassinate pirates, customize cool looking guns and all. Then this is still worthy of a buy. On sales it's very cheap so give it a shot.

The first-person shooter video game Far Cry 3 has an open-world setting and provides players with an experience that is both exhilarating and fascinating. The action of the game takes place on an island in the tropics, and players take on the character of Jason Brody, who is tasked with rescuing his comrades from the clutches of treacherous pirates. The visuals are very amazing, and the locations have a lot of attention to detail; as a result, the experience is quite immersive. Players must travel the island, accomplish tasks, and improve their weapons and abilities in order to make progress in the game, which makes for a difficult yet gratifying gaming experience. The narrative of the game is intriguing, and its progression will keep players interested right up until the credits roll. The only real problem is that the game's side quests have a tendency to become boring after a while, but this does not take away from the experience of playing the game as a whole. For those who like first-person shooters and open-world games, Far Cry 3 is an absolute must-have.

The main issue is the online aspect of it; I think they call it 'game as a service'? The game still almost constantly checks for connection to this nonexistent service, which wastes a lot of time while playing and breaks any immersion you might have been experiencing. Still it has held up pretty well and has been fun to play, so there's that. a decent game.

[h1]NEGATIVES:[/h1]

[h1]RECOMMENDATION:[/h1]
[b]Get the game? Frak yes! Deal or not, if you loved previous Far Cry games, you WILL love this one! Buy it ASAP![/b]

This is such an improvement on the predecessors.  It was really enjoyable to play over 1 & 2.  They made some vast improvements to general gameplay, especially to fixing stealth, and character story and development, it feels like a much fuller game.  This was a step in the right direction.  It could have been harder on Master difficulty for my tastes, and certainly not as bad as malaria.

For the first time in the series, we see the hero is invested in the outcome, he has a horse in the race, and the game stays faithful to that pursuit to the end.  You're given quite a lot to do, if you like to string the game along and not rush through the main story too quickly.  The voice acting, particularly the villains, was really outstanding and the cinematics with Vaas in particular were crazy good.  The amount of personality he has was a lot of fun, in an evil way, and I found myself really looking forward to the next encounter. Quality stuff.  It almost made me root for him.  Maybe, a little bit I did.  

A couple things to note, keep an eye on your difficulty level, one or two times, it got bumped down for some reason.  I am adamant about playing the hardest difficulty whenever possible, and that really irked me, so watch out for that.   There is a "secret" quicksave on PC, F9 to quicksave, F11 to load the save.  For some reason, this is no where in the control mapping and it's not in the  tutorial sequence.  You can use it when you are not on a mission and in the mission area, but all other times, it can be very useful.  Otherwise, I did not encounter bugs that I can even recall.

As many others have said before, I wish there was a mixed option for reviews, since I do think that FC3 is a good enough game for a single playthrough of just the main story, but any more than that and you'd probably ruin the game for yourself.

I'll focus on the negatives and annoyances in this game since everyone already knows how Ubisoft games play.

The games full of technical problems of all types. I'll list some here:
1. Even though the game was ahead of its time visually, there's still visual faults and inconsistencies. The infamous SSAO options look really bad and almost make the game look like Borderlands because of that eyeliner look.
And indirectly lit scenes look weird.


2. The performance is awful on PC and the game's barely optimized. At 4k, the game only utilizes 60% of my GPU while being a micro-stuttering mess and consuming way too much power. 

3. The controls can be really annoying because there's many moments where your input gets ignored, or there's huge latency between you pressing something and the game responding. This can really ruin the combat.


The issues related to the mouse are the worst. 
First you'll notice that the game's sensitivty must be tweaked by modyfing the config files. Fair enough, tweaking configs is nothing new to people on PC. But the real pain starts once you realize that there's tons of options that must be edited outside of the game, including the graphics. 

The worst offender is the negative mouse acceleration, which in order to be disabled, requires you to download a packer/repacker program for the game's files. Something akin to winrar.

There's still more techincal problems to be mentioned, by I think you get the idea by now.

The rest of the problems lie in the gameplay itself.

The side activites feel like chores, with most of them being fetch missions. The voice acting accompanying them is ok at best.

The main missions feel unfairly difficult, since you mostly fight with the game's aforementioned techincal problems and not the enemies.

One of the unfair things that gets me is getting shot while stuck in animatons. There's so many moments where you're stuck in a healing animation where you still take full damage while it plays out. They should've made it so you take 90% less damage while healing basically.


Basically, a mostly fun, well thought out, mostly fair game, but one full of techincal problems.
This game's open world is a lot of fun to explore and shooting stuff is always fun.

In 2012 Ubisoft alongside Ubisoft Montreal Published and released Far Cry 3, an open-world first-person shooter. The game is set on a tropical island, and the players take on the role of Jason, a young man who is stranded on the island after a vacation gone wrong. The game has received critical acclaim for its immersive open-world gameplay, compelling story, and memorable characters. ‚ÄîWhich is why I bought it on PC to relive and experience the fun and chaos that is, Far Cry 3 (With better graphics and a frame rate higher than 30)

One of the key elements that set Far Cry 3 apart from Ubisoft's other open-world games is its vast and diverse environment. The island is full of lush jungles, sandy beaches, and towering mountains that players can explore to their heart's content. The island is also home to a wide variety of wildlife, including lions, bears, and even elephants! 

Another aspect that makes Far Cry 3 stand out is its engaging story and characters. Players will find themselves drawn into the story as they strive to rescue their friends from the island's ruthless pirates, led by Vaas. Vaas, who is voiced by Michael Mando, is widely considered to be one of the most memorable and iconic video game villains of all time, thanks to his sadistic and unhinged nature. ( "Did I ever tell you the definition of insanity?")

Far Cry 3 also offers a wide range of gameplay options, from stealthy and strategic to fast-paced and action-packed. Players can take on missions in a number of ways, whether that be by sneaking around and taking out enemies quietly, or by going in guns blazing. Additionally, players can also upgrade their skills and weapons, which allows them to take on tougher challenges and enemies as they progressed through the game.

Furthermore, Far Cry 3 also offers a wide range of side content. Players can take on various side missions, hunt for collectibles, etc. (That's how I got the Platnum Trophy lol). This allows players to enjoy their time on the island even more, and keep playing long after the main story.

In conclusion, I highly recommend Far Cry 3 to fans of the open-world genre. It offers a vast and diverse environment, a compelling story, memorable characters, and a wide range of gameplay options. It's considered one of the best games in the franchise. It's a game that anyone who enjoys open-world games, shooters, or a strong plot will appreciate. ‚ÄîIf only Ubi made more games like this :(

The game is absolutely fantastic. Got it on my 360 when it first came out and had a blast. I played it about 2 years ago with my 9700k and a 1660 and it was a great experience. Unfortunately I can't say the same for my new PC. I currently have a 3700x with an RTX 3090 and tried playing this game for old times sake. Forgetting the game is over 10 years old now I booted it up and was greeted to lets just say"unexpecting" frame rates. Video settings maxed out I can pull what seems to be maybe 50 fps consistently. After browsing Reddit I figured out that the engine really doesn't like modern hardware. It seems one can fix this problem with tweaking some of their computers components but I'm honestly just not into doing all this just to get the game running how I feel it should run. Its a shame considering this is my favourite title of the whole franchise and just spent $30 hoping to have a fun time with it. It truly is a great PC port... just not a great modern PC port. I'd recommend it to anyone, just not on a high performance rig like mine.

From the people that recommended this game to me by saying it's the best of all the Far Cry series - I'm pretty close in agreement! It has a different feel than 1, 2 and 4 but imo Far Cry 5, if it didn't have such a horrible story and that silly "get shot to death and dragged off somewhere" mechanic for it, THAT game would rival this in terms of gameplay (not story). There's just more hashed out gameplay mechanics at use in Far Cry 5 but the story ruins that game, unlike with Far Cry 3.

Story and characters is where Far Cry 3 really excels, along with the "Blood Dragon" expansion witch could have been a new release all on it's own. That unfortunately wasn't purchased through Steam though so I can't review that, although it's just as good as FC3 imo.

If you are into the FC series and want to play one that has a great story with great acting then this title is for you. It has the infancy of all the great mechanics that came into the other games but also has obvious work into a great story, which the other Far Cry (2, 4, 5 , 6) games seemed to completely forget to do. Note: I haven't played FC6 I've just heard that story is non-existent in that title also.

So typical Ubisoft, not a big fan of that company - they find out a gameplay loop that people enjoy and they barely do anything to it except change up locations and some mechanics here and there. After awhile that loop is so bored into your mind that you become bored with it (hehe, pun...). Also they are horrific at optimization. I fully expected I wouldn't have those problems due to how old it was. Unfortunately I was wrong. There was a crashing issue that I had to find a fix for through the community forums which for a game this late? Omg how incredibly lame. I had to edit game files in Notepad++ and debug the issue on my own. Many ppl couldn't even get this fix to work so imagine getting this game, playing for about 4 or 5 hours in (that's when the crash happens) and then it crashes and there's nothing you can do about it.

This EXACT SAME PROBLEM happened with Assassin's Creed: Origins. I got up to the point where my kid is stolen by Amun or whatever and the game crashed. Another time I had to find a fix by scouring the internet. If i wasn't so tech savvy I'm sure many don't find the fix at all and it ruins the game experience. The fix for Assassin's Creed: Origins? I had to DOWNGRADE my graphics card driver to play the game. So in other words, I just stopped playing it bc it made all my other games look like S***. Ubisoft isn't really worth it anymore due to these horrible optimization issues. I try hard to avoid their games just because of this one problem.

So, if you do decide to get this game then try and play as much as possible before the 2 hr. mark to see if you can get a return. I did this with Assassin's Creed: Origin's and it was the first time ever Steam couldn't give me a refund. After arguing with them long enough I found that it wasn't in their hands but Ubisoft. So tbh I had fun with this game but it also once again made me lose faith in Ubisoft and I'm weary of getting there games in the future.

Altogether I'd give it a 7.5/10.

By the time you find yourself about halfway through, it all starts to get a bit crazy with psychedelic trips and explosive shootouts. What was most interesting was Jason's changes in his personality, how he becomes intoxicated and consumed by the ways of the Island both mentally and physically, really interesting stuff.

Gunplay feels solid and there's s great selection of guns, as well as a list of what they call "Signature" guns, a short list of unique versions of some of the guns but with unique stats and attachments you cant get on the basic models. The sights weren't great I have to be honest, in fact most of them barring the red dot sight and the sniper rifle scopes were all blurry and thick, made it borderline impossible to see where I was aiming most of the time, not a major issue for me since I'm usually a close to mid-range type so I use red dot or iron sights, but could be problematic for mid to long-range types.

Now i'm a sucker for RPG games, so when a game with RPG elements comes around I can't help but fall in love. Been able to develop yourself and become faster, stronger, more resilient, more stealthy, better with weapons is something I appreciate, because it somewhat breaks up the monotony of a game just going "here's a gun, off you go" and FC3 does it better by adding that visual element of every upgrade been represented by another part of his tattoo been filled in on his arm. You really FEEL like you've grown over time, as if your time is been rewarded with strength.

Considering the location, its kinda hard to NOT make the map just look the same everywhere you go...its a Caribbean island full of shanty towns and militia, mountains and dirt roads from one end to the other...but the numerous ways of been able to travel around and the abundance of fast travel locations makes it a forgivable sin, especially once you get the glider suit...mobility is just so fun in FC3 and it feels smooth and so well implemented. The cars were, for the most part, fine though REALLY fucking slidey, I ended up ditching the car and just running most of the time, it was like I was playing 'Colin Mcrae Rally'...it wasn't an issue at first but eventually cars started to annoy me, but also they became rare to find by the second half of the game.

General pacing of the game is great, nothing feels like its too long so you get those little dopamine hits when you're rapidly ticking things off the list to hit that sweet sweet 100% mark.

Really good game, glad I finally got round to playing and finishing it, fully recommend!

[h1]An All Time Classic[/h1] 

Replaying this game for the sixth time, but on PC for the first time. 

I am instantly transported back to my twelve year old self. Whilst the graphics don't hold up too well these days, the story and game play is timeless. I was glad to see the FC3 story revisited in the FC6 DLC. 

There is very little to not love about this game. The characters are rich and believable, the story and setting and gritty and truly convey a feeling of being a "far cry" away from home. The game play and wide array of weapons are also to be commended, truly pushed the limits for a game of the era. 

At the time of release (2012), Far Cry 3 was part of a relatively underground series from a big studio. Everyone knew Assassins Creed, but Far Cry was one of Ubisoft's more hidden gems. This game changed that forever. 2012 was a year of massive releases such as Black Ops 2, Mass Effect 3, Halo 4, Borderlands 2, and Diablo 3, yet Far Cry 3 held its own, winning game of the year. 

A true classic, remembered forever by me and many others.

Overall 6/10 - Great Story, good gun play, but gets really repetitive and boring in the middle.  

Jason's drive into madness is illustrated very clearly for all audiences and is akin to the themes circulating in the public eye as of writing this in 2022, which include the lack of self-expression men have in contemporary oppressive corporate life, illustrated by Liza in the game and Jason's friends talking careers, which men like Jason break out of through escapist means, now turned literal.  
Like American Psycho, Jason's murder spree and enjoyment of such liberates him, and the island strips everyone of status and hones in on the primal instincts of hunt, survive, and "you versus them."  

The guns handle well, but everything's pretty slow to use.  It takes a solid 2 seconds to swap guns, reloading medium size guns like rifles at max speed still takes at least 3 seconds, and crafting things on the fly isn't a thing - you have to go into the menu to do that.  It might seem small, but this means that the speed of combat is limited.   
The melee kills are sleek and stylish - very nice to drop on two guys, stab both, then run up on a guy, stab him, and use his knife to throw at another guy.
I don't like this port to PC because the slots still assume you're on console.  You can only have enough slots as you have slots on a d-pad, and everything is inaccessible through number keys - you have to use a weapon wheel for things like C4 and mines.  

Ubisoft, ubisoft, ubisoft.  
This is one of the OGs so I can't fault it, but it's Ubisoft so you know what you're signing up for: go, climb tower, complete checklist missions, clear outposts, repeat.  Granted, clearing outposts are fun, but everything in this game besides the story is repeated for too long and it gets really sickening to have to play through it all.

I never played many FPS games in my youth. Not like most people, and not like most fans of this game. I'm probably one of the few people who actually never played an M rated game until he was old enough. Yet I subconsciously remembered this game, not by watching or recommendation, but one little radio song...

It was around 2018, I found a mashup on SoundCloud of "Tide is High" by Blondie, mashed up with Charles Brotman & Jim Wolfe's "Ukulele Girl". Sadly I can't seem to find the mashup anywhere online anymore, but believe me when I say it was beautiful- unbridled joy & harmony. Listening to that on the bus rides to and from school in my senior year, it was a real vibe. Stuck with me forever as a real standout memory. I'd then look up each song individually after listening so much, and searching Ukulele girl on YouTube- that's when I heard the name Far Cry 3. The comments section was full of fans shouting out the game, and their memories driving through the jungle. It really is just a beautiful song, and it, along with those comments, stuck with me.

Years later, 2022: I'm going through a weird patch of my life, but at least I've got more times to play games. In fact, after playing so much TF2, I was actually craving a singleplayer FPS. One that was like a laid-back open world sandbox. That's when I remembered, that ukulele game... Far Cry 3! Oh hey whaddo ya know, an open world sandbox FPS! I mean yeah it sucked that UPlay was gone as of buying it, but it wasn't gonna put down my intrinsic interest over the course of years. So I picked it up on a Black Friday sale and...

Wow... What a hallmark of a video game.

When I finally played it, I couldn't believe how iconic this game was. From all the Vaas cutscenes I've seen ages ago through memes but repressed in my memory, to the many staple open world mechanics I've seen elsewhere. I had no clue it all traced back to Far Cry 3. But even then, this game seriously surprised me in so many ways, and really hit me in a way it only could today, after what I've been through in my recent life.

As I write this review, it is Far Cry 3's 10th anniversary, and also the day I completed the game. Like so many others years ago, I've become a lifelong fan. In the 5 days I played it straight, I thank this game dearly for cheering me up from my sadness with its good fun, for some amazing memories with some spectacular missions, and for helping me reflect on my own life thanks to the stellar character writing. It's not too late for a Game of the Year, is it? Game of the Decade??

Again, I never played many FPS games, and had no idea what Far Cry 3 was about even before buying it. I went in knowing nearly nothing. I certainly never expected to find one of my favorite games ever through a single song. Guess that's the staying power of music, right? All these years later, I wanna say...
Thanks Ukulele Girl, you really did rock my world.

Uplay/Ubisoft Connect is the only thing that ruins this experience in my eyes. I love playing timeless, classic games like these, but not when they're locked behind an entirely different launcher that I have to make a new account for just to play. I understand this doesn't just apply to Ubisoft, but it's a little disappointing that there are no achievements, at least for Steam. Achievements are locked behind Uplay, which... I don't know a single person in this world who actively seeks Uplay achievements. I would probably be a lot more inclined to put more hours into this game otherwise. But as of now, it's definitely just a one time experience for me.

Ubisoft aside, this game is pretty fun. You can finish all the missions in two days, which is what I did. It's a very fast-moving game. The pacing is weird, but it's a Ubisoft game made in 2012, so... Certain missions were absolutely tedious, but Vaas is such a captivating antagonist that his few minutes of screen time makes up for some of the more lackluster parts of the experience.

The game gives you an option to buy any unlocked gun in store, but you could just get these weapons for free by activating radio towers anyway. Some of these guns are absurdly overpowered when it comes to upgrades, though. The most powerful sniper rifle in this game is able to support three attachments, so, if you have a Z93 with a silencer, extended mag, and a high power scope, you‚Äôre pretty much set in terms of hunting and stealth kills. Foliage in the north island is ample, so there is a lot of room for those things.

The driving in this game is kinda weird. It's very quick and spastic, but some places just will not let you drive uphill. Navigation is otherwise super simplistic. The map will pretty much do all your work for you. It automatically marks locations of animals, outposts, story missions, side missions, etc. For the campaign, you‚Äôre given 38 story missions. Everything else ‚Äì the outposts, the bulletin board, the supply drops ‚Äì is completely optional. The story is only linear until the very end. If you‚Äôre looking to play casually, I would just play on standard difficulty. It's not that hard of a game to beat, especially when most of it is optionally a stealth game.

Gameplay wise the game is fine, but the motion sickness is terrible in Far Cry 3.  I've never gotten motion sickness with other games such as COD, DOOM, etc, but this one makes me really ill.  I'm pretty certain it's all the unexpected movements your player camera makes.  Looking at the ground a lot while moving and only looking up to shoot helps a bit.  The drug trip scene was the worst - I had to pause it halfway through and come back an hour later to finish it.

It's also kind of annoying have to log in to Ubisoft Connect every time to play, and it complaining that it can't connect to the online services.  At least it's playable.

The best part of forced, unnecessary online mechanisms in a fundamentally soloplayer game?  Being forced to log into an integration with the absolutely worst launcher in the whole of video games (Ubisoft Connect) so that when you get into the game you can be showered with "failed to connect" messages every time you open a menu.

Frankly, they should remove this game from the store because, frankly, it's not worth preserving.  The thin veneer of this being a unique story-focused jungle-themed sandbox about survival and revenge in the wild rapidly gets stripped away throughout the course of the story as it degrades to the most generic one-liner action movie with the same mission set pieces you've seen 1000 times before. Insulting story, insulting dialog, insulting game mechanics that don't even work half the time because they don't interact well with the set piece the game pre-programmed.  It's not possible to turn my brain off enough to not despise this game.

This game is a beautiful melting pot of open world exploration, stealth, minor puzzle solving, high octane action sequences and character levelling woven brilliantly into one of the best story plots i have witnessed yet.

The world is not too large neither too small. Getting from point A to point B without fast travel should not take more than 5 minutes by vehicles. Still, the option of fast travel is a boon.
The exploration feels very balanced as the rewards for exploring are useful but not a mandatory grind.
The same can be said for levelling up your skill set and character. (Higher levels are obviously required later on in the endgame)

The plot isn't too rushed neither does it drag on for ages. The side quests are just short enough and varied enough to keep the player engaged. The collectibles are abundant and it may take a while to gather all of them. But for the completionist in me, it is just the right amount to not put me off from the grind.

The character development arcs for a lot of the main characters are really well thought out and the voice acting is spot on for certain characters. The protagonist, Vaas, Sam, Hoyt, Citra, Ernhardt all have a certain charm to them and definitely contribute to making this game memorable.

[hr][/hr]

Of course with the level of detail added to the open world i would expect to find some weird graphics knick knacks here and there. For example, waterfalls don't blend smoothly into the water body below them.  Viewing far away sceneries through your camera shows some random light flashes (don't know if its intentional).
I had a few major bugs too where the game would suddenly crash out of nowhere and i would have to start over from my last autosaved checkpoint or save state. This did get on my nerves too as it happened a handful of times, but i wouldn't hold it against the game itself and more against the developers not providing support for this game anymore. 

[hr][/hr]

All in all, taking all the positive things about the game (of which there is a lot), and the negative things about the game (crashes, extremely minor graphics bugs and some game startup issues) i would give the steam copy of this game a solid [h3]9.3/10[/h3].

Definitely worth buying and trying.

---{ Story }---
You wake up a captive of some pirates on a tropical island. You escape and become Rambo within the first hour of the game. You must rescue your friends from the pirates, who are actually drug lords. It's really not gripping me. It's like it was written by an adolescent boy. The cut-scenes are frequent, long, and un-skippable. 

---{ Gameplay }---
It's unforgiving. Big game will survive point blank shotgun blasts to the face, and can two-shot you. Human enemies have superhuman powers of observation, and their aim is impeccable. Stealth is problematic. Enemies will spot you from a mile away, and will then be able to track you no matter what. On the other hand, you can Quake into enemy encampments, just keep running and gunning, and brute force your way through the task. They were trying for realism, but... in reality a stealth sniper would survive, Rambo wouldn't. The whole experience was immersion-breaking for me. It feels like the AI is cheating, and yet still losing. Cheap deaths just waste one's time. I feel like Ubisoft tried to imitate games like Half-Life (and 2), and F.E.A.R., but just stuffed it all up. The driving isn't as bad as everyone says, it's the roads that suck. Way too many QTEs. 

---{ Graphics }---
They are undeniably pretty for a ten year old game. The lighting and reflection especially are done very well. 

---{ Audio }---
Average. The voice-acting is bad. The music is great. 

---{ Difficulty }---
I don't know. Not so much difficult, just annoying. I get the sense that everything is do-able if you just push through it, but it's a chore. Feels like luck is more important than skill or strategy. 

---{ Grind }---
It's Ubisoft, most of this game is busy-work.

---{ Bugs }---
Oh yes. It keeps wanting to connect to the online servers every time i go to the menu. The map is bugged out. Sometimes i'll accidentally vault over a stationary object and take damage for no reason. Sustaining fall damage for no reason. 

---{ PC Requirements }---
Max settings on an i5-9600K and an RTX 2070 = consistent 60fps.

---{ 5 / 10 }---
I'll finish it, but i'll never touch it again.

Far Cry 3 is an game that brought the Far Cry series to the mainstream. the first game was revolutionary, but for it's was in the shadow of bigger projects. Far Cry 2 is too niche and weird for most people. Far Cry 3 hits that sweet spot of mass appeal, while being tight, focused, and enjoyable game with interesting story and mechanics. 

The story of the game follows Jason Brody, a rich white kid that picked a bad place for a vacation. He and his friends are now victims of pirates of the Rook Island. Thankfully Jason is holding the power of the protagonist, which gives him the impervious plot armor. With his badass abilities and natural inclanation to kil people, Jason will save his friends and destroy evil pirates. In all serioussness, the story is actually pretty interesting. Jason is really just a kid that got in trouble in the wrong place at the wrong time. His story is the one of transformation and losing his humanity. While he is in a horrible situation, he treats it all like a game, the Rook Island is just a giant amusement park, while very real suffering of the indigenous people of the island, reakyat, are just the set dressing and the outlet for his fantasies. Everything is elevated further with a strong supporting cast. The main star, is, of course, Vaas, the main villain of the first part of the story. His incredible monologues paired with superb acting from Michael Mando make him steal the scene every time he's on screen. 

The graphics hold up in the game pretty well. The move from dusty African savanna back into tropical island was a very solid choice on the developers part. Everything is so fulll of life and color, really sells the idea of tropical paradise. There are trade offs, of course. every character model that is not a named character looks fromw weird to downright bad. Not to mention copypasted NPCs that do nothing and just walk around in the neverending loop. There is also weird texture popping, I'm not really sure what was causing it, but some stuff was just rendering itself in front camera, which wasn't supposed to happen. But overall, the game is stable and free from major bugs.

The gameplay is really simple. Take the blueprint of FC2, remove most of the annoying stuff from it, apply Assassin's Creed formula on top, and in the result we get a very nice open-world shooter. While the shootuots are way less chaotic due to the absense of weapon degradation, we get much more new features here. The towers, that Jason has to climb to unlock more of the visible map, while become pretty much a joke in Ubisoft titles, are a pretty easy way to incentify exploration and give players meaningful rewards if the form of weapon unlocks. Jason starts the game really weak, and first few hours could be a struggle without unlocks, but you get strong really quickly with the hunting and leveling up. Leveling up is represented with the tatau, a religious tattoo of the rakyat people. The upgrades are small increments, but add to make Jason a perful warrior really quickly. the side activities are varied and can be interesting, like the trials of rakyat thwhere you have to get high scores by killing enemies with certain weapons, or very boring, like the supply drops, where you have to make a delivery in time. And like in a true ubisoft fashion, there are five billion of useless collectibles that give you pretty much nothing but bragging rights. Okay, not that many, but they are still pretty useless. 
The shooting is still pretty good, the enemies react to your actions in mostly reasonable ways, the arsenal is big and satisfying, made even better with the so-called "signature" weapons, with more attachments and improvements to stats. The big improvement this time is stealth, where you have much more information about the location and abilities of your enemies, as well as how well you hide from them. The new one button takedowns are a big feature that should be utilised in every opportunity, and allow you to kill entire camps unnoticed. The outposts from FC2 are back as well, but this time they don't work like instant cloning stations that dispense enemies every five minutes. Now outposts could be taken for the rakyat warriors and taking the outpotsts will liberate the region from pirates, allowing friendly rakyat warriors to spawn and help you in fights. To unfortunate downsideto this system is that there will be no further interactions with the piretes in the open worldoutside of smissions, since when you liberate every outpost, the pirates will stop spawning and only will be an issue in story missions.

While Far Cry 3 isn't as dark, chaoutic, or hardcore as FC2, it's still a very enjoyable game. The improvements to the gameplay make the game much more approachable and interesting, the story is surpisingly great, and the graphics do hold  up even almost 10 years later. The issues are few and far between, and the only true sin of this game is that it made us notice Ubisoft's copy-pasted bullshit in their open-world titles. While formulaic and mainstream, FC3 is great for what it is.

Steam Deck Reservation FAQ

While Steam Deck is now in stock and shipping, our production, processing, and shipping bandwidth is still finite. If order volume for a specific model of Steam Deck grows higher than our ability to ship it in a timely manner, delivery estimates will lengthen, and at a certain point we‚Äôll flip back into reservation mode until we‚Äôre able to catch up.

Why is there a reservation fee?
The main reason for reservations is to ensure an orderly and fair ordering process for customers when Steam Deck inventory becomes available. The additional fee gives us a clearer signal of intent to purchase, which gives us better data to balance supply chain, inventory, and regional distribution.

How does the reservation system work?
When you submit a reservation, you will be put in a queue. Once inventory is available, you will be emailed in the order the reservations were made.

When will I be able to order?
Once you receive your order invitation you will have 72 hours to complete your purchase - if you do not complete your purchase or cancel your reservation, your reservation slot will pass to the next person in the queue.

Can I cancel my reservation?
Yes, you can cancel your reservation on this page. If you cancel within 30 days, you will be refunded to whatever payment method you used. If you cancel after 30 days, your reservation fee will be refunded to your Steam Wallet.

What regions can I reserve Steam Deck from?
Customers in the United States, Canada, European Union, and the United Kingdom can reserve a Steam Deck from this page. Customers in Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, and Hong Kong can reserve a Steam Deck by visiting Komodo at steamdeck.komodo.jp

How many Steam Decks can I reserve?
One Steam account can have one active Steam Deck reservation at a time.

What happens to my reservation fee if I do not order my Steam Deck in time?
Your reservation fee will be refunded in full. If your refund occurs within 30 days of your initial reservation, you will be refunded to whatever payment method you used. If your refund occurs after 30 days of your initial reservation, you will be refunded to your Steam Wallet.

Are there any restrictions on users that can reserve the Steam Deck?
Your Steam account must be in a valid country.

Do I need a Steam account to use Steam Deck?
The default Steam Deck experience requires a Steam account (it's free!). Games are purchased and downloaded using the Steam Store. That said, Steam Deck is a PC so you can install third party software and operating systems.

What if I'm not able to reserve right now and would like to purchase a Steam Deck in the future?
You may add Steam Deck to your wishlist and we will notify you when it is available for general purchase.

Is the reservation queue regional?
Yes, the reservation queue and expected order availability times are specific to each region.

Can I change which Steam Deck I purchase once I'm able to order?
Once you're able to order, you can only purchase the Steam Deck model that you reserved.

When will I be charged in full for Steam Deck?
Once your reserved Steam Deck is available and you complete your purchase, you will be charged.

Does the reservation fee count towards my Steam Deck purchase price?
Yes.

Far Cry 3 is an open world FPS, with some elements of stealth. It features a large tropical island full of pirates to fight off and wildlife to hunt, upgradable gear and different tactical skills to progress through the story‚Ä¶ Er, once you actually play it.

It‚Äôs an easy recommended game, even though it‚Äôs a bit old and the franchise has come a long way since it came out. Thus, I‚Äôll go through the worst parts first.

The most important thing to keep in mind is that, although it features a truly open world, the greatest focus of the main game and most of the side content is combat. This is, there is no real ‚Äúexploration‚Äù (most things that you might want to discover can be pinpointed through the purchase of maps), all the obstacle courses seem to be more of a mandatory procedure than something they really wanted to exploit (Ubisoft and their obsession with climbing up towers), there are no interesting characters outside of the main story. 

Collectibles, although easy to acquire, are way too numerous and don‚Äôt really serve a greater purpose besides just playing into completionist‚Äôs OCD. As I said, they aren‚Äôt an actual challenge to get and although a couple unlock recipes or a couple weapons, the game would work basically the same without them.

Also, the first half of the game is AWESOME. The second half is a bit disappointing. In the game there are two islands, each one with their part of the story (although the second part is slightly shorter) and side content. Well, in the second part the side content feels really pointless and tiresome by that point (on early playthroughs I would always collect everything on the first island and just rush through the second one without picking a single collectible), and the story is only saved by one good character, feeling the rest of it, again, pointless.

Last, but not least, be warned that this game is cursed with Ubisoft Connect, to be able to run it. And I‚Äôm gonna dedicate a couple of lines to this launcher: If you are gonna force it on people, at least show the store properly (it allegedly hides it if you only have Steam-owned games ???) and don‚Äôt allow me to create a password that goes over the character limit the first time the account is created.

Now, with that aside, how well does this game hold nowadays?

Well, I‚Äôve played the game back in the day very little after launch. Then I played it many times afterwards‚Ä¶ Then I played through it again recently, completing all the side content, and somehow it still manages to be a lot of fun.

Few games come close to the joy I get whenever I want to play this game again. Far Cry 4, for instance, didn‚Äôt manage to even catch my attention for more than a couple hours.

The gameplay in this shooter is just one of the best. The guns feel alright, are distinctive enough in feel and only a few of them seem useless. Yes, you‚Äôll eventually just choose your favorite 4 and blast through the rest of the game with them, but in the meantime, most of them hold on their own.

You have many choices of pistols, assault rifles, LMG and SMG‚Ä¶ Besides powerful (and kinda game breaking) sniper rifles. You get your classic RPG, a grenade launcher‚Ä¶ And of course a flammenwerfer. And finally, the almighty bow, which can use special arrows to set stuff on fire or just blow it all up, if you are not a fan of its inherent stealthiness. Add to this C4, landmines, molotov and your good old frag grenade‚Ä¶ And you get many choices to take it out to the pirates for kidnaping your friends.

Most of them are customizable to slightly change their stats or usage (nothing crazy, but useful things like supresors or larger magazines) and give them a paint coat (still nothing crazy, 6 choices per gun, patterns of one-two colors or a texture coating like wood).

Besides that, you get a set of upgradable abilities that increase your tactical choices. Many related to the melee-instant-kill ability that you have (which include special death abilities like chaining insta kills or using your enemies‚Äô grenades or pistols against them), which greatly rewards stealthy approaches (and I say this despite really disliking stealth in games), plus enhanced healing, speed, resistances‚Ä¶

By themselves, the abilities aren‚Äôt that interesting, but given the ‚Äúopen feel‚Äù for combat in this game, the many approaches you can take, the different weapons that you‚Äôll be using and your needs in each situation‚Ä¶ They manage to give an interesting and noticeable edge as you acquire them.

To this, you can add the crafting system. Lots of gun-related upgrades are obtained by hunting animals, skinning them (some you‚Äôll only face in special hunts) and crafting upgrades: New holsters, greater ammo bags‚Ä¶ And the same system is used with plants that you can gather around the island to get special abilities.

These go from almost anecdotal given how contextual they are (longer underwater ‚Äúbreathing‚Äù, an aid to find plants despite the fact that they are EVERYWHERE)... To be really useful: Immunity to fire, being able to sense wildlife for hunting‚Ä¶ And all the way up to being stupidly overpowered (one hit kills with weapons or straight up IMMORTALITY).

This just adds to the tactical depth that this game achieves with just a few well made mechanics.

And how is this exploited?

Well, besides the main story, which contains many fights to test all these mechanics out, there is a particular part of the side content that usually is people‚Äôs favorite: Outposts. These are enemy bases that you have to free by killing everyone posted. Usually they have set patrols that you can exploit to eliminate them silently and prevent them from triggering the alarm and calling reinforcements in. But hell, it‚Äôs also just as enjoyable when everything goes wrong and you have to run around the base trying to save yourself. It‚Äôs only a shame that this mechanic ties into the enemy‚Äôs presence in the surrounding region, meaning that as you complete this the territory becomes more secure (meaning you won‚Äôt meet enemies on the road). Still, a worthy and really nice mechanic.

Besides that you have the aforementioned hunt of wildlife for crafting materials, as a secondary mission or just for the kick of it, plus hunting enemy‚Äôs officials. Also some special ‚Äúarena‚Äù missions where you face many enemies at once while being restricted to a special rule: Being able to use only grenades, or only an RPG, or even being able to only run them over.

Besides these combat-focused activities, you have some others like poker, racing or knife throwing. These unfortunately don‚Äôt seem that interesting to me, that‚Äôs why I say that most of this game is focused on combat. This includes secondary missions, which strangely almost never exploit combat and are focused on fetching quests (guess it‚Äôs an attempt to bring variety but)... Although, a couple of them are interesting and may have a somewhat funny plot twist.

Finally, I would like to talk about the story. Of course, the best part of it is whatever focuses on FC3‚Äôs poster boy: Vaas Montenegro. It‚Äôs always a show when he‚Äôs around (you will notices this literally the first 5 minutes of game) and makes up for an interesting, intimidating and hateable antagonist, whose purpose is questioned to go beyond what is directly shown (for me the character works even without these ‚Äúhigher purposes‚Äù people talk about, so I‚Äôm reluctant to give Ubisoft more credit than they deserve). Still, although I agree that it‚Äôs a really good character, it feels like it overshadows other characters that have their own thing going on. There are many characters (all but one in the first half of the game) that are worthwhile meeting and many tense and action packed situations in the game. 

If you are looking for a short FPS experience which doesn‚Äôt have a right way to be played, and as long as you aren‚Äôt looking for an open world with anything to do besides combat, this game is for you. Really fair price on sales, it‚Äôs a great bridge between classic and modern FPS
One of the best single-players ever made.

I actually bought all Farcry games available on Steam including all it‚Äôs DLC, but I‚Äôm going to be honest‚Ä¶ what Ubisoft doing right now is quite a D*ck move since we paid for this game to enjoy it anytime we want or every time we feel playing it again‚Ä¶ I even have to rush to get all achievement available on single player because I‚Äôm afraid that I will never get it ever again after the developer stop the support for this game. Still no matter how s*it the developer is‚Ä¶ I can‚Äôt deny that the game is really fun to play.

For me this is the best Far Cry game. Kind of a master piece. Though Far Cry 2 is also a masterpiece, this game took the franchise to the next level. Now we have a living breathing world with animals, both human and otherwise. Kill animals and use their parts to upgrade your gear. You can even kill sharks. Explore a lush world. Use tons of weapons and vehicles to take over a wide variety of enemy targets. Find treasures and collectibles. Pick from a skill tree that allows you to specialize in range, melee, or stealth playing styles. All of these are executed to perfectly. When this game came out it looked stunningly good. Today it still looks decent.

But like all things south of heaven, this game has flaws. For many one of the highlights of the game was the main villain. I found him a joke, like one of those melodramatic campy Batman villains. Luckily I easily avoided him by not doing much of the main quest. 

Unfortunately the main quest proved to be a problem as well. This game touts freedom of choice but violates this expressed ideal by making you do some of the quests in an exact way. One quest stopped my progress dead by demanding I follow a specific sequence of steps exactly as the developers wanted. When I failed, I had to replay that 5 minutes all over again. Which made the game a Ground Hogs Day simulator, where I played the same 5 minutes over a dozen times. If the game wasn't using an auto-save or save-point feature, this tedium could have been avoided. For me this was almost a game breaker. 

For those of us playing on Steam, there is the added problem of Ubisoft. For some reason the developers insist that we log into their launcher. The console did this too, but it did it less evasively. Wow, this is a big game. I've been playing it for close to 30 hours so far, and I can't find much about it that I don't like. First off, the good stuff.... lots to do, lots of bad guys to beat up on, a great story, a "fast travel system", and an environment like no other. The landscape doesn't repeat and you can tell that every inch of the island had a lot of thought put into it. As for the stuff I really didn't care for, well, I could do without the "tripping on drugs" stages (so far about three of them). Frankly, it's been done to death and they're pointless. Also, I don't like is that, some hills and mountains are impassable on foot and you can't determine that by merely looking at them. Maybe if there was some more opportunities for air travel, it wouldn't be such a big deal. But, on the other hand, the vehicles you use drive fast enough on the road so that it becomes a small matter after all. I'm also not crazy about the missions where you have to climb not one, but eighteen, creaking, dilapidated radio towers to reactivate them. They're way too difficult. One false step and you plummet all the way to the bottom to start again. I remember playing one of these missions for over fifty-five minutes. Those things aside, two thumbs up.

[b]Special review section for Ubisoft games:[/b]
[u]Should you play?[/u] YEP
[u]Should you BUY???[/u] NOPE

[b]Comment:[/b]
After a breakthrough first game and a unevenly received second game Ubisoft struck gold with the third title. It had just the right amount of fun with bits from the previous games and good new additions. Game is most fun when it does not force you into stealth or using a specific weapon. When you have freedom to do stuff how you like it is immense fun. Possibly the strongest part of the game. Liberating camps highlights this the most. Don't get me wrong, stealth parts and weapon challenges are good too but getting to choose how you approach is where FC3 shines. Campaign limits you in this regard as it forces you into scenarios, with the late missions just rushing you with endless enemy soldiers. I found enjoyment here too (despite the wild voice acting for Jason) with Vaas of course being the best part of it by a lot. All of this is done with a big variety of weapons that sound and behave great. Further adding their usefulness by modifying them. To bolster the playtime they added TONS of collectibles - relics, letters and loot chests. Normally it's tedious but finding ways to get to some is an interesting challenge. Although the amount of loot chests is a bit much. There are also other parts to love (like crafting) or hate (like a damn tiger ambushing you for the fifth time). Now for the final point - this game is great and you should try it. But giving money to Ubisoft, when they are removing access to the full experience (DLC, uPlay unlocks, multiplayer), feels wrong. Twelve years ago people were making concerns this might happen and Ubi said it wouldn't and yet come 10/2022 it is happening. Play it if you have it already, but I cannot recommend supporting this publisher with your money...

[b]P.S.:[/b] [strike]There are some DLCs available for this game that are not part of the standard installation. [u]Deluxe Edition DLCs:[/u] The Lost Expedition (2 missions), The Monkey Business Pack (4 missions), The Warrior Pack (dagger), The Predator Pack (sniper rifle), artwork & soundtrack; [u]High Tides DLC Pack[/u] 2 coop maps & 4 new skins (made part of standard edition later); [u]uPlay unlockable DLCs:[/u] Original Track - Far Cry 3 (soundtrack), Exclusive Assignment (mission), Revolving gift (revolver), Tattoo Pack (multiplayer skins).[/strike] [u]You have to go to Options and then Downloadable Content and type in the key. Having DLC downloaded via Steam and the Deluxe key activated on uPlay is not enough. [b]All of this extra content is made unavailable from 10/2022 if not already activated.[/b][/u]

Oh my god. Where should i begin? What should I say that has not already been said? This is one of the best singleplayer experiences I have ever had. Why? The environment is beautiful, with the blue ocean and the flush green grass. But the story is really where the game shines in my opinion. The story is pretty straight forward, and never wastes to much time on anything. I always felt like I war progressing towards my goals. I do not think I progressed to fast, nor to slow, and I never lost interest. I also really enjoyed the gameplay. The stealth is what you would expect from a Far Cry game. Sneaking up behind enemies and stabbing them through the chest with a machete. Also hunting for animal skins to upgrade for example the amount of healing you can carry. The gunplay I found to be decent. The variation of guns was good, but i will say many of the guns lacked recoil, and felt very light. I would have liked a bit more weightiness to the guns. There is some gun customization, like different scopes and mags, but it could have been a bit more fleshed out. The soundtrack is an absolute masterpiece. Over all I give Far Cry 3 a 9/10.

[h1][b]Quick Summary (TL;DR):[/b][/h1]
[b]Graphics:[/b] - Slightly dated and somewhat saturated look, but still a nice and competently made game to look at

Nice, dumb open world fun that is very "Of its time," for reasons both good and bad.

It is an action flick in video game form, meant to appeal to your average dudebro gamer while actually retaining a semblance of quality, y'know, back when video games were meant to be fun?

The gameplay is solid, but somewhat repetitive, especially if you're going for 100% upgrades or progression as a whole, (Rest your soul, you're in for tedium galore in that front) but it's still good overall. There's not much to say about it besides simplified open world FPS shenanigans with stealth because why not.

The storytelling, however, is simultaneously impactful and stilted, falling to the wayside at times for the sake of the gameplay being able to hold up, and the plotline to be cohesive enough for things to actually happen, If it sounds like a strange thing to say, it's only because of the fact that there are times where the cinematics will lampshade impossible situations away via misdirection through major story beats. If you play the game, you'll know what I mean when you see it.
There's also a sex scene for some reason.

Overall though, it's a fun game.

It's okay.  Like Assassin's Creed there are plenty of sidequests and adventures to be had on the island in addition to the main storyline.  Not quite as much fun as AC, though as they are mostly finding chests or relics, doing some stupidax job for a local islander, or running medicine over an insane terrain on a vehicle with poor handling.  This last one is made fun by being able to kill the doctor to whom you are delivering the medicine (not in the game, I just made that adventure up).  The stealth hunts are pretty good and I enjoyed both liberating outposts and hunting down ne'erdowells.  Hunting animals is meh.  As for the main story line it is both unbelievable and annoying.  The protagonist is a whiny little cuss with whiny little teenage friends so you almost want to spoiler them all in the spoiler, but of course if you do then spoiler even though you get to spoiler with the skanky heroin addict island queen.  The gameplay was generally fun, but the betatesters could have done more to fix some of the glitches; doorways difficult to enter, jumps and climbs hard to stick, enemies attacking you from inside a rock?  These made the gameplay a little on the annoying/tedious side.  Overall, it was an amusing little slaughter fest that pitted a scrawny teenage wimp against hardened mercenaries, tigers, and annoying jump scareagators, but I could take it or leave it.  Not much on the replay value & without any achievements it hardly seemed worth it to complete the quests after I toasted off the main storyline and watched el skankeroona get a knife in the spoiler.  Anyway.  Try it.  You might like it.

This is not a good game - and it's not because of the Ubisoft Launcher. 
Read on and I'll help you understand why.

Okay. Let's do this. You don't know until the combat starts - but your character actually has X-Ray vision!
Yes... Really...

Once you shoot an enemy all his movements and location are forever highlighted to you without any explanation as to why. Meaning that if the enemy runs away to hide behind a brick wall - who cares! You can still clearly see him highlighted anyway.

The game has no immersion what so ever -  Allow me another example to explain it to you:

It's a Sandbox Game that isn't a Sandbox Game at all.
This is not Skyrim with guns.

The game presents a huge island to explore. That is, unless you have a mission to do.
If your character leaves the mission area the game will force you to teleport you back to the start of the mission area. How immersive.

This and many other annoyances leaves the player feeling like the game is constantly slapping you on the wrist and saying "Bad player. Play how we say!!"

The game is way too easy and running in shooting has almost no downsides whatsoever as landing a head shot rewards just as much XP as a stealth kill, despite requiring less set up and less skill. 

This game treats the player as an idiot in many different ways. As far as I can tell after a few hours, so far it's impossible to fail a mission.

Not skilled enough to stealth into a camp? - Who cares, just carry on!
You can't fail the missions!! This game treats the player like an idiot.

All the bad guys use the AK47, which means after you pick one up you're never worrying about ammo ever again. Non of the guns seem to have any recoil mechanics.

The game looks very impressive - but a quarter of the screen is taken up by a Mini Map you can never toggle off and if you're on a mission you better believe the missions paragraph long description takes up the left hand side of your HUD too.

Farcry 3 cleverly tricks the player by using what I can only describe as a 'fake distance'. 
Meaning although you can clearly see mountains and such in the background the actual local area visible is only ever quite limited but disguised in quite a clever way, even on Ultra graphics settings.

As a console port the FOV is a decent 110, along with Direct X11 and Ultra graphic settings do make the game look very nice. However in the middle of a thick jungle at night time without lamps or fire  it isn't actually dark.

Aside from some good visuals and good characters (the main bad guy is actually really decent and interesting) the game is weak in so many areas. I'm glad i picked it up for ¬£3.75 last Christmas.
I would have been devastated to pay full price for this effort.

Avoid it and play one of the much better shooters out there -  unless you're after an easy no brainer FPS, to hold your hand as you play.
I have always been a fan of the "Farcry Style" and all of the farcry titles!

I wholeheartedly recommend it.

The dude is facing you with a gun, you press a button and an animation begins where you slaughter the defenseless dude by charging at him.

Astonishingly unoptimized. The game is pretty good, but Ubisoft evidently does not care about players being able to access   and play their older games. They want you to spend money under the illusion that you'll be able to play. No matter your rig, you can expect choppy, unimpressive performance and lots of stuttering and frame drops. This game should run easily at ultra settings given its age and mediocre appearance, but poor optimization makes this impossible. There are a number of potential solutions to Ubisoft's optimization failures available online with varying impacts on performance, but none of them bring this game remotely close to the performance that one should expect from this decade old title.
Attempting to get this game to a playable state is accompanied by additional headaches in the form of an intrusive and buggy Uplay (that is required to run any Ubisoft game). Currently I'm stuck in a loop where, whenever I want to start the game, I get a message that they're unable to verify my ownership of the game product. The solution to this is to sign out, and then sign back into Uplay. Logging back in requires a mandatory two-step verification to my email. To start the game from here, I have to, for a third time, enter my password to play the game I already paid for, from 2012, that struggles to achieve even choppy inconsistent 40 fps on hardware that plays Witcher 3 at 60fps on high. It's almost like a slap in the face.
The most depressing aspect of Ubisoft's negligence is that it is most likely intentional, so that they can keep the door open for any potential remakes or remasters of this game in the future. This is supported by the fact that Ubi will be removing many of these "potentially remaster worthy" titles off of the storefront soon. I can't imagine that sending out a small update improving compatibility would be difficult, but Ubi would rather chase short-term profits on their latest titles (which are also not great. FC6 is full of bullet sponges, disgustingly bad writing, and bad game design decisions that could have only come from the mind of an out-of-touch, lead-paint-addled moron - which seems like it would be an accurate descriptor for all of  Ubisoft's current writing staff). 
Ubi would be able to garner a lot of public goodwill and appreciation if they devoted a team to maintaining playability/optimization for their older games and keeping them available on the storefront, but that will never happen. All I can hope for is that a natural disaster will hit every Ubisoft location and destroy all their servers in some kind of divine act of justice.
Do not pay for this game.

I've never heard anything but praise for Far Cry 3, and I've been working my way through the Far Cry series so I was really expecting to enjoy this game at least a little bit. Despite that, Far Cry 3 is one of the most unpleasant gaming experiences I've ever seen through to the end. 

The game itself is mediocre, adding stealth mechanics which actually reduce the potential for stealth relative to Far Cry 2, while constantly forcing you into big gunfights near the end despite the subpar and unsatisfying gunplay. The UI is incredibly cluttered and drops all of the good ideas from Far Cry 2, which had a barebones HUD and gave you a physical item to use as your in-game map to increase immersion. In contrast to Far Cry 2, Far Cry 3 constantly distracts you with pop-ups and alerts, has an unpleasantly cluttered menu, and arbitrarily locks down various weapons and abilities, all of which make the experience just a little bit less pleasant. I had to download a mod just to make the pop-ups tolerable. The radio towers are at best annoying to climb, and at worst a nightmare as the game triggers jump animations that send you right off the side. Overall, a mediocre game.

The story, on the other hand, isn't mediocre: it's horrible. Major spoilers follow, obviously.

Jason Brody is the worst protagonist I've ever had to embody in a video game. His voice actor is BAD. Everything he says sounds childish. He goes from being (understandably) terrified to trying to sound threatening in about an hour of gameplay, and it is hilarious how bad at it he is. Brody's character just sucks, and so do those of all of his friends. They're all rich Californians with little to no personality. No one has any good motivations for their actions whatsoever. Brody starts out trying to save his friends, and quickly ""goes native"" and becomes violent and bent on vengeance. It appears to take no push whatsoever do this to him. He starts going crazy and rejecting his friends within a few days of being on the island, presumably because he wants to fuck Citra just that badly.

Speaking of ""going native,"" holy shit this game is racist. Brody is a typical white savior archetype who is instantly hailed as the hero of the Rakyat despite having arrived on the island 30 minutes ago. He is regularly held up as the only hope of the Rakyat, who have been fighting a guerrilla war without his help for years at this point. There is no explanation given for why the Rakyat cannot retake the utterly unguarded radio towers or the sparsely defended northern outposts. Despite the natives technically being /your/ faction in the game, there are no major native characters except for Citra and Vaas, both of whom are insane villains. Most of the native women npcs are prostitutes, and you often find them dead and littered around the island, which would be fine in this setting if there were some native women npcs who were anything else, but there aren't. In fact, none of the Rakyat ever seem to do anything useful without Jason Brody around. The game is also filled with lines saying the jungle makes you violent and crazy, and this type of violence is just inherent to the setting, despite the fact that all of the Rakyat live here and they seem just fine when they're not fighting off pirates. They use hallucinogenic drugs which give you literal visions of the future, and you get magic tattoos which make you a member of the tribe despite the fact that you never actually have to talk to any of its members. And I almost forgot to mention the character of Dennis the Magical Negro, who gives you your tattoo and appears to induct you into the Rakyat at the beginning of the game. He apparently went through the same process as you and plays the role of a stereotypical Magical Negro until the game discards him.

Citra, again, one of only two named natives in the main story, is a stereotype to her core with little to no depth. An "indian princess"-style temptress who encourages Jason to help the Rakyat with her wiles, the entirety of her personality is "I'm hot and I want to fuck you, the player." She pretends to fall in love with you after a grand total of two interactions, which Jason buys completely. Her motivations are never explained. Her leadership of the Rakyat? Never explained. 

Beyond the racism and bad voice acting, the story has more holes than swiss cheese. There is a magic Chinese knife which, for some reason, inserts itself into the story for a grand total of 3 pointless and nonsensical fetch quests, and is not seen again until the end. How did Vaas's men get into the ancient ruins you needed a magical compass to find? Why did Buck need your help getting any of the compass pieces when he already knew where the knife was? What was the point of Buck's character? He comes in for two hours of play time to lead you to this knife, he makes cryptic comments at each point, the reason he wants the knife or knows what it is is never given, and then you kill him in one of the hallucination knife fights reserved for major bosses like Vaas and Hoyt. In fact, no one ever explains why they want the knife. They never even explain how they know it exists. All of a sudden, a third of the way through game, everyone and their mother is searching for the knife and then it just ceases to be relevant at all. It appears to be sacred to the Rakyat somehow, judging by its usage in rituals once Citra gets it, which makes no sense, since the knife is repeatedly stated to be a not-that-old Chinese artifact, even by Citra!

Last but certainly not least, Vaas. There is nothing more disappointing in this game than Vaas. Vaas is the only character in this game with a good voice actor. He was interesting because he seemed to be a non-native (he turned out to be a native), because he might have been a good foil for Brody (this was never explored), because he didn't seem motivated by drugs and money like the pirates he worked with (but it turned out he was), and because he was clever and outsmarted you repeatedly (though the "Surprise, Vaas is Behind You!" trick did get old. Jason needs to learn to check his corners). His compound looked fantastic on the inside (though you only see that style once), and generally Vaas had the potential to be a good villain. Except you kill him, halfway through the game, and he is replaced by his incredibly boring boss, Hoyt. He is also, again, the only other named native in the main story. His backstory? Handwaved away in one line. 


All in all, I'm not sure if I regret playing Far Cry 3, but I won't be recommending it to anyone else.
